reviewText:
Ohhh yeah look at that grass! These leaves are rendered beautifully. And, my god, look at the water, I can see my perfectly modeled reflection!
Can you run Crysis, or can you not run Crysis? That is the question. If you can, you are one in a million. You are part of an elite organization dedicated to the eradication of visible polygon edges. You strive to inform the world of the dangers of trillinear filtering. But you also laugh as you run 5 different instances of Crysis at the same time, while the average gamer struggles to complete a game of minesweeper. As you watch your maximized particle effects without frame tearing you get a sense of superiority that is, well, frankly justified.
Besides prestige and graphics, Crysis does offer great gameplay. The plot makes you feel, it makes you want more. The freeroam approach to objectives lets you choose your style. And at the end of the game you are just left in amazement at the 10 hour, non-stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥ you just had.
So If you want to inflate your ego or just want a fantastic game pick up a copy of Crysis today... if you think you can handle it.

reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
NOTE: I originally finished the game using my disc based copy of the game bought in 2007. I bought it again on steam because it was included in the Crysis Franchise Pack.

INTRODUCTION:One of the rare PC Exclusive titles to break free from the Console's restrictive and dated hardware. Crysis 1 was the benchmark for most PC games back in 2007 until it was finally replaced by Metro 2033 in 2010.

Crysis follows the story of Jake Nomad" Dunn
date: member of a Delta Ops Nano Team tasked with infiltrating an Island currently occupied by North Korean Forces. Not soon after landing
recommended: the Delta team finds out that the KPA is the least of their worries.\n\nPROS:+ Cutting Edge Graphics: -Considering this game was released in 2007
hoursPlayed: Crysis can still go toe-to-toe with the 2012 game Far Cry 3. Back then
voteText:
almost 95% of all PCs in the world could not run Crysis on its maximum settings. Crysis 1 was meant to be a PC only exclusive mostly because the developers really wanted to push both their creative freedom and raw hardware power. This is the game also spawned the internet meme: "But can it run Crysis?"

+ Innovative Gameplay: -This game was the first to introduce the Nano Suit which added a wide variety of new approaches to missions and objectives. A Quick hand and good reflexes are needed to fully utilize the Nano Suit's power.

+ Pseudo Open World: -Its not Sandbox
helpfulPercent: but it's not linear. Each mission objective involves a map of gigantic proportions where you can go and carefully plan out your strategy before going in a mission. Like what I said in my SW: Republic Commando Review
votesHelpful: not every game needs to be sandbox. Crysis 1 had a good style by giving enough freedom while keeping the player in a directed flow in the story.\n\nCONS:- Terrible Optimization: -Although it was the Graphical Flagship of its time
votesTotal: the devs mainly focused on sheer brute force power of the GPU but made so little optimization. If properly optimized
votesFunny:
most mid-range PCs could have ran this game a bit better.

- Unresolved Bugs: -6 years and some of the bugs from the first release still persists. Downloading some of the latest patches actually causes a bug. Not game breaking but terribly annoying.

- Resolution Problem: -You may or may not encounter this problem but the game seems to have a problem doing a full screen with a 1920x1080 resolution. To fix this
commentsCount:
you'll need to edit the settings via note pad.

CONCLUSION:MUST HAVE. One of the landmark games that dared a primarily Console dominated market to shine a great light once more to the PC.

Additional Note: This is not a fast paced action game like COD or Battlefield. This game actually requires some planning and tactical movements to get the job done
column16:
specially in some of the harder difficulties.

reviewText:
After what....six years now?....this is still one of my faves. I still come back and play it periodically. Never get tired of the skulking around you can do, then open up fire on a few baddies for a while....then go back to skulking. This and the expansion pack Crysis Warhead are just a kick.

Sort of like Call of Duty meets HL2, but with more hi-tech baddies and then some pretty mean aliens both big and small. Exceptionally weaponry at times as well.

It's engaging on a lot of levels. You get your action on for a while. You get to sneak up on enemies and eliminate them in fun and interesting ways. And it challenges you to find sneaky means of taking them out. Even cooler: there are dozens of ways of attacking, and you can go back when replaying and try various new things and methods.

Even better: it's as complex and slow-moving as you want, or you can force combat into a faster pace. Out-freaking-standing game

reviewText:
Crysis, better than FarCry.

+ Amazing shooting, felt great.
+ Very large open world, with alright level design.
+ Almost everything has physics, you can mow down trees to blowing up shacks.
+ One of the best looking games from 2007.
+ Everyone's voice work was great, except Helina's...
+ You can see your legs.
+ The story was... alright.

- Crashed a lot, had to Google a solution.
- Some of the body physics were wonky.
- You literally don't need any other rifle than the AK.
- It's only toggle zoom, instead of hold down right mouse button. It felt weird to me, may not be a problem for others.
- TAC Cannon Ex Machina.
- A few plot holes.
- If you don't grab the TAC Cannon before the final boss, you're unable to complete it. That's bull sh*t.
- Not enough checkpoints (at least you can quicksave).
- A little short, pick it up on sale.

7/10, very good game and one of the prettiest and most fun FPSs out there.

reviewText:
It took me a while to be fond of this game as I played it years ago and while my rig met the minimum requirements (almost reached the recommended ones) it had a hard time running Crysis on it properly. There were numerous glitches, audio issues and frequent CTDs.

But you know what? Putting the technical difficulties aside this is a damn fine game! You play Nomad, a special forces soldier who wears a so-called nanosuit. The story takes place in the future and the objective is to find out what happened on the island previously seized by Koreans.

While you traverse through the deep jungle and small settlements you notice two things: the game is stunningly beautiful (there was a reason for the high system reqs) and that by hiding-shooting you cannot eliminate your foes. You need to utilise your nanosuit.

You can bring up a special menu and select from various abilities. Speed makes you faster, Strength allows you to melee your foes or throw bigger objects and Stealth makes you invisible. All drain your energy bar (which will refill automatically, but slowly) and I do not have to mention that Stealth is the most exciting and most useful among all. Oh, yes, there's a 4th power enabling you to take more damage.

Enemy AI is great - they respond to the noises, work in squads and will try to find you even if you are invisible. On greater difficulty settings they speak Korean so you do not understand what commands they give to one another.

Occasionally, the game throws in some scripted cutscenes - these look good and also interesting. By looking at the pictures on the store page one can guess what they'll find (and what the army was really looking into), but let's not spoil it here.

Crysis is a stunningly beautiful game (even today considering it's more than 5 years old) and makes for an interesting, action-packed ride.

WARNING: This review is based on playing the game on a 32-bit operating system. As per the feedbacks on the store page and amongst the discussions people detail further issues when it comes to 64-bit systems. I understand there is a workaround which has been tried and found good, still, this is just to let you know that before the purchase you should look into this.

reviewText:
I've never ever felt so confused about rating something I have just finished. At the moment I'm talking about story and its side of game because other parts of game (which we'll be talking next) are perfect.

On the release date (2007) was this game truly revolutionary. In that time game's graphic was something unbelieveable. And still when we're comparing nowadays games or games from at least from 2010+ we can see, that Crysis is still next step above them and not in graphic, but in whole gameplay, even stealth and sometimes AI. This game is damn 7 YEARS OLD for God's sake and still nowadays developers are not even able to put their games to level Crysis was in 2007 which's really unbelieveable.

My PERSONAL opinion is, that if there weren't aliens and SCI-FI side, it'd be one of the best FPS games ever been made. At the moment I got my hands on my head, and thinking of words which could describe the first hours of game. Alright, I'll divide this game to 2 parts ... 1st with Koreans and 2nd with Aliens. If the whole game was only about Koreans .... I still have no idea why they've put Aliens in it... Just because they had to think of new story ? Ridicolous, since the story flew 5 hours without problem and without mentioning Aliens... They really have could let it in only.

There was mentioned stealth, so let's take a look on it. It's really different, than in nowadays games. Now, when you hide into creek or tree, or just some textures which obviously should cover you, you're automatically spotted because in source code they're just textures, but in Crysis somehow you was able to cover in creek or tree and enemy could be few feets away from you, and he didn't spot you which's realistic I'd say. But of course only if you stood still. If you made a move, he could hear you obviously, so also as I said AI is pretty good made here. When you're in firefight, they won't rush you, they'll wait for you, throwing grenades on you, but in open field, they wan't to crush you from sides which really doesn't matter since you got Nanosuit...

Multiplayer is totally dead. No wonder when this game is 7 years old. Still you can find servers with 30+ players, but only sometimes, and they're different version than Steam version (Servers for cracked copies) and there are only 10 servers for Steam version which're empty and when there is someone, he's cheater anyway. MP won't change rating.

To the end let's say, apart from fact there're Aliens it's still awesome, great, brilliant, and one of the best FPS ever been made, but not BEST. Crytek always knew how to make games (not these days .. NOTE: F2P). The ending was one of the worst I have ever encounter. Ending of game took me 10 hours in total and parts with Aliens was like 3+ hours.

8/10 (Perfect)

reviewText:
A normal game PC nowadays is able to play Crysis like it was meant to be played. I upgraded my (7 year old) PC earlier this year, and therefore Crysis finally became playable for me. Because, let's be honest, a game like this should be played maxed out. So I picked it up at a recent discount on Steam, but was it worth the long wait?

I really enjoyed the game, but from time to time it really got me frustrated as well. I struggled with the checkpoint system of the game a bit, but maybe that's because I'm not used to it. Ultimately, I have a good feeling after finishing it and that is the most important factor for me.

Anno 2013, Crysis still is a stunningly beautifull game, and you no longer need extra-terrestrial hardware to play this game on very high settings. However, the last level is very demanding on the system, and I had to run the game in DirectX 9 mode to be able to stay above 60FPS (just add -dx9 as a startup argument).

So, all in all, do I recommend this game... yes (if you can pick it up a at a discounted price of course).

reviewText:
Crysis is a  first-person shooter game developed by Crytek and published by Electronic Arts in 2007.

An elite group travels to North Korea to investigate an artifact. While the player faces Korean soldiers and research facilities , an alien ship prepares to emerge and begin the invasion of Earth . Nomad  faces Korean forces and tries to defeat the alien threat . The game submerges us under incredibly detailed rainforests. The physics of the game is excellent . Apart from the story, one enjoys walking around the environment , breaking the palms, catching animals, piloting boats , swimming with fish , and driving around the islands.

The graphics engine is the successor to Far Cry . It was a real revolution in real-time graphics . The image quality and texture is still among the best of all time . This makes the game very immersive . It took five years after release to play the game with very high quality settings and get  a reasonable experience. Many people spoke at the time of bad optimization when in fact the game has three times more polygons than his contemporaries , volumetric clouds , day- night phases and huge maps. Nothing compared to the fixed pixelated sky on a Call of Duty game .

The player has a special suit that gives different powers or abilities for a period of time, such as invisibility , speed or armor. While it is not a Sandbox, it has  open maps that simulate the world much better than its very linear successor, Crysis 2. In that regard, it is even better than Crysis 3.

The game was one of the best action games of 2007 but did not have many sales due to high specifications, hardware requirements and DirectX 10. It has two Secuels . Crysis 2 and Crysis 3 .
While Crysis 3 surpasses some of its graphic , 1 remains the best game of the 3 .

The game was released for Windows PC , PS3 and XBOX 360 before being ported to MAC OSX.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
ESPAÑOL
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Crysis es un videojuego de disparos en primera persona desarrollado por Crytek y distribuido por Electronic Arts en 2007.

Un grupo de elite viaja a Corea del Norte a investigar un artefacto. Mientras que el jugador se enfrenta a soldados coreanos e investiga instalaciones, una nave alienígena se prepara para emerger y comenzar la invasión de la tierra. Jake Nomad deberá enfrentarse a las fuerzas coreanas y alienígneas para intentar derrotarlas. El juego nos lleva por selvas tropicales increiblemente detalladas. La física del juego es excelente. Al margen de la historia uno disfruta de pasear por el entorno, romper las palmeras, agarrar animales, pilotar lanchas, nadar con peces y manejar vehículos por las islas.

El motor gráfico es el sucesor del Far Cry. Fue una verdadera revolución en cuanto a gráficos en tiempo real. La calidad de imagen y texturas sigue estando entre las mejores de todos los tiempos. Esto hace al juego muy inmersivo. Recién después de cinco años pudo jugarse el juego con la calidad máxima activada y una experiencia razonable. Mucha gente habló en su momento de mala optimización cuando en realidad el juego tenia tres veces mas polígonos que sus contemporaneos, nubes volumétricas, fases dia - noche y mapas enormes. Nada que ver con el cielo pixelado y fijo de un Call of Duty.

El jugador posee un traje especial que le confiere poderes especiales por un lapso de tiempo, como la invisibilidad, la velocidad o armadura. Si bien no es un Sandbox posee mapas que simulan un mundo abierto mucho mejor que su muy lineal sucesor, el Crysis 2.

El juego fue uno de los mejores juegos de acción de 2007 aunque no tuvo muchas ventas debido a las altas especificaciones y el requerimiento de DirectX 10 para aprovecharlo al máximo. Posee dos seculas. El Crysis 2 y el Crysis 3.
Si bien el Crysis 3 lo supera en algunos de sus aspectos gráficos, el 1 sigue siendo el mejor de los 3.

El juego se lanzó para PC bajo Windows, PS3 y XBOX 360 para luego ser portado a MAC OSX.

reviewText: The graphics in this game are amazing, even when compared to a lot of current-gen games. This was truly ahead of it's time. Of course, there are some minor flaws which are commonly seen in first-person open world games, mainly problems with the enemies being dumb as soup cans even on difficulties above easy. But, in defense, the game was made to be eyecandy and not to be a gameplay masterpiece. Still, the stealth, the weapons, the vehicles, the open world and the missions all make Crysis most certainly worth it's price tag. Also, you're best off getting the maximum edition, because it includes Crysis Warhead, which just adds to the experience. So, despite it's flaws, I give Crysis a solid 9.5/10.

reviewText:
Warning, contains mild (Edit: heavy) spoilers.

Never having played the famous Crysis, I thought I'd finally give it a shot and find out what the fuss is all about. Naturally, since I played this in 2014, my perspective on the game will be very different from the one who played it when it came out. But only an hour into the game, I realized why people call it such a revolutionary shooter for its time. I didn't play with any mods, yet I would've never guessed the game I was playing came out in 2007 judging from what it presented to me. This is due to the following reasons:

- The vastness of the world and the graphical fidelity are overwhelmingly impressive for an FPS title this old. You can clearly see that the CryEngine is designed to push the limits on what's possible in terms of looks and scope. I was impressed by how open-world-y the terrain is, yet the missions are unmistakably straightforward... which turns out to be an incredibly fun combination in my opinion. Being dropped on a tropical island where you shoot people in a vast and open area offering multiple ways of approaching your goals is to my mind a great way to design an FPS. The level of detail is stunning to say the least for a 2007 title, I have seen much worse in considerably newer titles.

- The gunplay, gun variety and AI are simply great. Shooting enemies feels fun, feels rewarding and feels challenging since the AI actively tries to hunt you down when you for example sneaked away again using cloak. One of the core mechanics, the exosuit and its accompanying suit powers offer great variety for both people who like to be stealthy or those who love to cause mayhem. I found a mix of these to be the most effective and entertaining. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it I think I never experienced as much satisfaction as when I blew up a truck with a rocket launcher while crouching in a bush with cloak engaged. The effects are mindblowing, as are the sound assets, just really immersive overall.

- Performance is solid. With CFX 7950/7970 I easily manage 60fps, except for very intense scenes involving lots of explosions and stuff. FoV seems to be exceptionally high, I didn't see a slider for it in the menu, but it's at least 100 by default, which is great. Sadly there's a few bugs involving for example scripted events and cutscenes not triggering correctly when loading from quicksaves amidst a level, nothing game-breaking though. Also, 1920x1080 or higher resolution is not enabled by default, you have to manually adjust it in the config file, which is no big deal though.

- The level design is interesting enough. While most levels feature open tropical island terrain with hilly, foresty areas, there's also a sequence where you are in weightless space, floating around inside a gigantic alien structure; very impressive and intriguing overall. The enemy variety is great too: From your usual infantry of all kind to jeeps, tanks, helicopters, boats to rather pesky flying alien crystalline squids with fast-firing energy weapons to a huge ♥♥♥ alien motherfugger in the process of sinking a motherfuggin aircraft carrier. It should be noted that you can drive jeeps, tanks, boats and helicopters yourself which is super fun if you like to shoot up stuff in the most classy way imaginable.

Negative points? I have one major one, but perhaps it's not really valid since the game clearly doesn't focus on that aspect at all and never pretends to:

The story is mindblowingly clichée and superficial: >Technologically augmented super soldier infiltrates fictional island under the control of evil North Koreans, gathers intel, blows up stuff, uncovers archeological project gone overboard, sleeping alien entity that feeds itself off energy awakens, causes major destruction, gruffy American general wants to drop nuke on island to kill off the monstrosity, super-intelligent scientists who always know it better advise against it, alien gets nuked anyway, becomes massively stronger, protagonist has to beat XXL format version of alien monstrosity using lots of missiles and a super secret prototype weapon which had never been field-tested but works like a charm (why wouldn't it?), escapes a sinking aircraft carrier and goes right back into the fight because he's a badass and a superhuman, dutiful soldier-tough-guy who has no fear and throughout the entire game requires no sleep at all.
There, that's the plot in a nutshell for you. Not really intentended in the beginning but hey, these are spontaneous and minimally structured reviews after all so w/e.
So there you go, awesome FPS, don't play it for the story, play it for the mechanics and the looks. This is how every modern military shooter should be. You can make a very linear, bland narrative without sacrificing diversity and creativity in terms of gameplay and mechanics. Crysis taught us this.

No score here, read the damn review if you care for my opinion on it.

reviewText:
Do you miss first person action games like GoldenEye, Thief 2, and the original Ghost Recon? If you miss games that simply put you in an environment, gave you some objectives, and let you figure out how to do them without driving you down a rollercoaster, the original Crysis is arguably the last and most technically advanced game of this type to be developed. The visual achievements of the CryEngine have overshadowed the fact that this game, well most of it at least, is a shining example of objective-based game design released just before everyone took shooters in the complete opposite direction.

The first level, which is shown off in the demo that’s available at crysisdemo.com as of this writing, is a perfect example of this. In a small bay occupied by a few enemy fortifications along the shore and some motorboat patrols, Crysis gives you two main objectives and an optional objective to tackle in any order. You can work your way along the coastline through the forts, take over a boat to zip around the bay, or whatever, through any combination of stealth and assault tactics.

This continues through the next several levels which are sort of a linear chain of small sandboxes: a village you can infiltrate from multiple angles, a group of bases along a river, a harbor, and so-on. The level design in all these areas is quite good, always giving you options and setups for fire fights that never happen the same way twice. This is even true in the game’s more linear sections early on. In the early parts (more on that later), even when Crysis is a corridor it’s still a very wide corridor.

I think the best way to describe the core game mechanics would be to call Crysis a simulation based on the original 1987 Predator movie. Your tools are Schwarzenegger-esque explosions and futuristic super powers. The nanosuit let’s you choose between super armor (the default), increased running speed, and a temporary stealth cloak. You’ll probably use the cloak the most but the other powers offer potential for fun combinations and interesting choices. Super strength let’s you jump higher, and you can combine it with speed for running super jumps. When sniping you can choose between staying hidden with the cloak or using strength for a more stable shooting arm.

Behind the nanosuit the Crysis boasts a varied sandbox of shooter mechanics. Not only is there the ever-present option of stealth, but you can also lift and throw most objects at enemies and control various vehicles. Most buildings in the game are also dynamically destructible through the physics engine, which feels like it has a tangible effect on gameplay. Crysis even let’s you fit most weapons with a modest variety of attachments with a quick tap of the C key like different sights or a silencer.

The reason you might hear a lot of people praise Crysis by saying “the first half” or “the first two thirds” of the game, is because for some reason it turns into a different, much worse game at a specific point later on. The later sections of Crysis are far more linear and introduce gameplay mechanics that while unique, just don’t work that well.  It’s probably best if you stop playing when you start a boss fight with a North Korean general. The most succinct thing I can say is at that point it feels like the level designers ran out of gas.

The good parts of Crysis though will still net you at least around 10 hours of gameplay, and that’s just for one run. I consider Crysis to be a pretty replayable game just because you can approach its missions with multiple strategies, but also because each difficulty mode above normal changes things considerably.

On normal you can pretty much toy with enemies using the nanosuit. On hard you can still play with them a little bit, but you have to be smart about it. Higher difficulties change a few core mechanics, and the deadlier enemies ensure you have to rethink the way you use the cloak and cover. Hard and Delta mode almost turn Crysis into a straight-up stealth game.

Of course what Crysis is most well-known for is the “but can it run Crysis?” joke pertaining to the game’s harsh treatment of processors. Even after six years, Crysis is not an extremely easy game to run. My GTX 760 still only get’s 60 frames per second MOST of the time in 1080p. The consumer experience when you first install the game doesn’t make things easier either.

Being from the early days of DirectX 10, Crysis forces it on you by artificially locking the highest graphics features behind DX10 when they are in fact available on DX9 just by editing the ini file or downloading a custom one. DX10 does little more than drag down performance of the already demanding Crysis.

If you’re wondering if Crysis still holds up visually after six years, I think with vanilla settings it’s beginning to show its age, but still looks significantly better than most console games released in even the last couple years. Really, only the highest-end recent PC games (Crysis 3, Metro, Battlefield 4), and next-gen-console-only launch games like Killzone Shadow Fall beat it. It can still look impressive with custom ini files and texture packs though.

I think it’s kind of a crime Crysis got labled as just “that really pretty PC game nobody can run.” In my opinion it’s one of the most underrated first person shooters of this past console generation (it did come out on consoles eventually after all), if not one of the best. It’s one of the last, if not the last of a breed of shooter that game designers seemingly forgot in the chase after Call of Duty’s popularity.

If I look back to the early 2008 this was nearly a bomb for me; always wanted to play it, playing through and again, again, again.

Improvise or use tactic methods; weapon mods or the abillities of your armor. Get a vehicle, fill it with explosives and drive it into an enemy outpost, no problem. reviewText:
For a long time, I had Crysis down as a graphics demonstration; all the looks & headlines but with no substance. Hardly surprising when all that was talked about was 'Can it Crysis?'.

However, I picked it up cheap in 2010 after building a fresh system & wanted to see what it could do.

It was only when I found I was riveted to the game did I realise that underneither the headline grabbing garphics, was a game that utterly appealled to me; it's a seriously immersive story that holds on to you for hour after hour.

The game play is excellent, switching suit modes is fast & intuitive, the gun upgrades are all worth considering & best of all you can be gung-ho if you want or you can stealth you way around & not really kill anyone & still acheive the mission objectives, the game simply sets you're objective, then lets you crack on with it, rather than forcing you one way or another, a trait that defines utterly iconic games like Deus-Ex.

The vehicles handle like boats though, much like Farcry, Crytek's first game & the climax is a little overblown. It's dramatic & exciting, right up until you fight the final 'boss'. However, like Bioshock, the build up is so enjoyable, any final battle is going to feel like an anticlimax.

Ultimately, the game ended with me chewing my hands for more, which means that it's succeeded in engrossing me in the world it's creating, which is the one thing I demand. An excellent multiplayer is all well & good, but if a game has a story line, in my mind, it has to stand on that alone or not at all. Crysis doesn't need the graphics or EA's massive marketing department to be a truly noteable game, but it does help make us aware of it.

reviewText:
Crysis was a very good game and the first in a great series developed by Crytek and published by Electronic Arts in 2007. Crysis is a science-fiction first person shooter. You, the player, play as Nomad, an exceptional and strong-willed character determined to fight to survive. The game is primarily set on a North-Korean controlled island where they are attempting to uncover the mystery of a potential grand discovery. Nomad and his nano-suited military team mates and the United States army intervene, however the reveal of a greater power, named the Ceph, strongly influences and alters the story.

This campaign is excellent. The campaign is a great example of a story that starts slow, but builds to a climax. The setting of being on one island suggests a limited campaign, however, the great areas of on the island and in the island create a nice variety of missions. I adore the fluidity and transition between missions within the campaign. For instance, you complete a mission and run to the extraction point - instead of the game taking you to a loading screen, it immediately starts the next mission, which is a massive positive. The only issue I encountered with the campaign is the mild relevance of the side missions. Nomad would have to gain intel from a North Korean camp, and while it adds some further dialogue in the story, it is not substantial. Also, it is really a standalone player game as your squad-members do not assist you in missions and are very useless.

Gameplay is your standard first person shooter gameplay, The gameplay is fluid and solid. There is nothing more to elaborate on regarding shooting and cover. Driving is a nice feature but clunky as the vehicle is very sensitive to player controls. The issues I encountered within the gameplay section is the lack of ammo for an American gun and the very small variety of overall guns in the game. I had to rely on a North Korean assault rifle because there was no ammo to be found for my American Scar. There are some minor bugs such as the red dot on a red dot sight not appearing and the insane amount of bullets required to kill an armoured North Korean enemy. To kill an enemy would regularly take 75% of a magazine. To kill an Alien would take a larger amount of ammo, which is understandable as they are strong aliens, but for humans, that is very odd. The main disturbance regarding gameplay is the sheer stupidty of AI. Some enemies would run in circles while ally team mates would be useless in completing objectives, as stated prior.

The graphics are incredible for a game developed in 2007. Crytek is known as a high-quality graphical company and they really emphasised that in Crysis. While the recommended settings were a Nvidia GT 8800, I could not play at ultra settings, even with my graphics card, which is odd as I had to play on very high settings with V Sync and Anti Aliasing turned off.

Overall, this game is a good game. I only played the campaign and I can safely say I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. I played this game in around eight hours. It's a solid length of a game. I recommend the game at the Steam price of $19.99. Furthermore, I would strongly suggest buying the Maximum Edition that includes Crysis, Crysis: Warhead, and Crysis II.

Three aspects in review:
Campaign: 9/10
Gameplay: 7.25/10
Graphics: 8/10
Overall: 8.25/10

Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews

http://store.steampowered.com/app/17300

reviewText:
This review is for the game ''Crysis'',a first-person shooter video game,developed by the video game company Crytek.
The game was published by Electronic Arts and released in November 13 on 2007(in North America) for Microsoft Windows.The game uses the CryEngine 2 and was later upgraded to CryEngine 3(not for Microsoft Windows though).

Plot
You are Nomad,a delta force soldier,who with the use of his military nanosuit's capabilities (Maximum Strength,Maximum Speed,Maxim Armor and Cloak) his weapons,vehicles and with his other military friends and along the way acquaintances has to engage enemies(firstly Koreans then bloodthirst aliens) in order to save the world from the possible alien domination.

Gameplay:The player can  encounter enemies in a variety of ways.You can use short ranged weapons or ranged rifles,use stealth and surprise your enemies by attacking them from behind(either killing them swiftly or tranquilizing them) or just aggressivly kill whatever moves by spraying bullets all over their bodies.Game includes a high variety of weapons such as:pistols,assault rifles,sub-machine guns,missile launchers,gauss rifles,shotguns,miniguns,the TAC gun and the MOAC all of which can be customized through several attachments like the sniper scope,the iron sight scope etc.In addition you can use
many vehicles like hovercrafts,jeeps,acp,vtol etc

reviewText: Crysis is one of the best looking FPS games out there which features realistic looking jungles with awesome action. What makes this FPS different than others is that you are powered with a nano-suit which lets you choose different powers (speed, strength, shield or cloak) at a time which allows the player to play the game however they choose - either be stealthy, run and gun, or just tank the bullets. There are a handful of different guns to use and each can be customized a limited amount. The story is decent and somewhat unique as the setting takes place on an island that the North Koreans forces have occupied which you are sent to investigate a lost team trying to see what they have uncovered. The campaign runs around 6 - 8 hours which makes an all around fun experience.

reviewText:
Crysis is an excellent game and is very original. The most talked aspect about the game is possibly the graphics which by today are pretty, but back then they where so intense that it was almost unplayable on very high at 60fps (not including dual titans)

The gameplay is supreme as in the game is so open to random events that its can be quite diffrent from the last time you played it. You have a extremly straightforward objectives with many ways of tackling it, you could use stealth, straight action, or tactics. The invronment is so interactive that you could find so many things to do and get distracted from the main objective along with the interesting abilities, such as maximum speed,armor,strength and a cloak. The ai however is sort of dull at times and even made the hardest difficulty easy in which you could just alert some bad guys cloak infront of them and kill them all.

I would give this game a score of 9/10

reviewText:
Originally posted on January 21, 2010

Crysis is an absolutely incredible experience that defines why PC gaming is great. It's an open world shooter with graphics that are 2.5 years old and are still by far the most impressive offering on the market. It's gameplay is a varied hybrid of stealth and action in the proud tradition of Far Cry one, and although there are a few problems with the game, it is one you should not miss if you own a PC.

Gameplay-As in it's spiritual successor, Far Cry, Crysis is a game that centers around island/tropics based combat in an open world with lots of vehicles and baddies with great AI that can use vehicles, flank, retreat, give orders, and call in unscripted backup. You hit multiple objectives using stealth or assault tactics and a wide variety of weapons.

This much has not changed very much from Far Cry, and I see no problem with that. The AI very much Far Cry 1.5 AI, which is impressive considering Far Cry AI still tops many games on the market. Enemy vehicles still chase you relentlessly once you are discovered, and harder levels can be particularly brutal. You are not usually accompanied by many friendlies in a helpful manner, but there are certain fixed engagements where you encounter friendly AI, and they get the job done decently. It remains a lone-wolf experience for the majority of the game.

The most major change comes in the form of the nano-suit, which allows speed, jumping/punching, and armor to rise to greater levels at the expense of energy, and the suit includes a cloaking device. This simple mechanic allows for a huge amount of fun to be had, especially in jungle infantry combat and in enemy camps.

Another change would be the addition of on the fly weapon customization, a brilliant addition, and the ability to pick up attachments as you progress through the game. I will say that as gamers we do not always stop to examine the model of each weapon lying on the ground or even in an armory and as a result miss out on early instances of great attachments, such as the sniper scope. Could the auto-ammo-pick-up system from warhead be included in the next installment with a feature that picks up attachments you don't have as well? That would be wonderful. Also, the ability to suppress certain weapons would be welcome and not altogether unbalanced or unrealistic". I could envision the shotgun and sniper rifle being suppressed but with a louder sound signature and working in game just fine.

I will say the alien gameplay is a little less fun

reviewText:
I remember Crysis being known as the benchmark for graphics and processing when it originally came out back in 2007. I heard the console versions never did the game justice either. This year I was playing it for the first time and even now it's a remarkably beautiful game. The southeast Asia setting is  vibrant and complex, and the countless explosions is endless entertainment. However, for the most part the game plays out much like any other military styled FPS you've seen before but with suit modifications at your disposal; Speed, Strength, Cloak are enhanced at the cost of your armor. Nothing crazy. The Sci-Fi twist in the story is what makes this stand out amongst the other carbon copy shooter's and having no interest in the multiplayer I don't see much replay value. I recommend this game only when it's on sale for $5.

reviewText:
I'll get to the point here:

Crysis sets a standard in graphics fidelity up to this day thats' still unmatched by some current-gen games.
The story is not exactly top-notch (Sci-Fi, nanosuits and aliens, of course) but it does create a sandbox game worth playing whose length is perfect: Not so long and repetitive you'll begin cursing (Some CoDs out there) or so short you'll go WTF (Battlefield 3, anyone?).

In its' own right, this game has set a precedence of what we gamers expect when it comes to futuristic and forward game development. Up to date, this game still requires a PC with considerable power, a testament to its' developers' forward thinking as of its' time.

Overall personal rating: 8/10.

reviewText:
I only got round to playing Crysis in 2015, although I've been meaning to for years!

From what I'd seen, I was under the impression that you'd play a kind of semi-indestructable super soldier in this game, dashing and jumping around at high speed and slicing through dozens of enemy soldiers with ease, but really it plays more like you're just a fairly standard FPS soldier dude with a few perks. I found myself not bothering with things like the stealth and speed mode very often as they both drain your energy incredibly quickly. On hard difficulty, a few well-placed enemy bullets can still take you down if you're not careful so you don't really feel invulnerable.

The gameplay is fairly standard FPS fare, akin to Call Of Duty or whatever, with open-ish world elements but lots of set pieces. The game world never feels as open as, say, the Far Cry series and you are pretty much railroaded into tackling things in order, though how you approach each set piece is up to you and you do feel that you can take a variety of approaches to solve the obstacles you encounter.

The graphics have really stood the test of time, It didn't feel particularly dated.

My only gripe was that the campaign only took me 10 hours to play through - and I didn't exactly rush through it. If I'm honest, the storyline is also very standard and unengaging, following a rather cliched 'US saves the world from alien invasion that is unwittingly aided by the nasty Asians' formula that's all too familiar by now.

Overall, I'd say that if you're a fan of the FPS genre, you've never played Crysis before and you see if on sale for a few pounds/dollars (like I did) then it's definitely worth picking up! It's an enjoyable, if short, experience.

reviewText:
Crysis was a game that changed PC gaming in significant ways.  Release in 2007 the game is still fun, relevant, and beatiful all the years later (2014).

** GRAPHICS **
I just now have a computer that can run it with everything turned to max settings (1080p) and it is as good looking as most games being released now.  Many people say it requires a beefy machine because it is poorly optimized but I argue that even if that is the case, it still looks great!  The engine this game was built on has gone on to provide great graphics in many other games as well.

** GAME PLAY **
Crysis added a fun element to the game with temporary super powers".  Managing your super human suit abilities allowed a variety of game play not traditionally found in the FPS genre at the time of its release.  The game is good.  Its fun to play and to look at.

** Summary **
If you don't have it yet it is absolutely worth picking up at its bargain price.  It is a great FPS to sit down and play for a short stint or marathon with.  I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Crysis has had a strange life since it's release in 2007. At the time of it's release it was by far the most technologically challenging game to play, utilizing graphics that would make even the high end PC's of the time scream in terror. Because of this simple fact it was for the longest time mentioned in conversation much as one would mention a benchmark tool and throughout gaming, that is how it was viewed. A measure of the strength of your PC. A strange fate for a game.

Although there has never been much concern for the game beneath the graphics Crysis isn't a bad game. Although it does nothing new or revolutionary it is a good solid FPS that is spared the horrors of knee high walls that often afflicts other games in this genre.

You play as a super soldier wearing the Crytek version of power armor, a skintight bodysuit that lets you active various temporary abilities such as invisibility and bullet absorption. Although the attempt at stealth is fairly half-hearted the ability to leap 20 feet into the air and jump 60 miles per hour allows you to engage enemies in a variety of ways and that certainly helps keep the gunplay fresh.

The storyline is fairly standard, supersoldier stuff and the voice-acting doesn't go completely bad despite some poorly casted movie stars as your supporting cast.

All in all it's a fun play although not a game I think would have ever been made much noise about if it wasn't for the incredible graphics.

reviewText: I do highly recommend this game as I had played bits of Crysis a very long time ago and I was eager to purchase this game and play it.  I also highly recommend reading the specifications at the very bottom before purchasing and downloading.  I somehow seemed to misread or overlook all of the minor details of the game specifications before I purchased and downloaded it.  And with that, I simply cannot give this game a thumbs down when I had failed to misread or overlook the fact that I am running a 64-bit computer and I realized a few days later that Crysis is only available in the 32-bit version.  I am also running Windows 8 (which the system requirements say nothing about as far as compatibility issues are concerned).  And to make a long story short, I am currently unable to play Crysis.  I am hoping that another update/download for a 64-bit version of the game will become available sometime soon.

reviewText: Can your computer run Crysis?"\nDespite the fact that it has been many years since Crysis came out
date: you still hear this every once in a while (usually in jest). I definitely wasn't worried about my GTX 670 and i5-3750k having trouble.\n\nI had psyched myself up about the visuals so much that my initial impression was "well this doesn't look half bad..." and then I remembered how old the game is. And I nearly peed myself. Even the cutscenes were rendered in the game engine
recommended: so the game always had a consistent visual style.\n\nThe appeal for anybody who plays Crysis is of course the beautiful graphics
hoursPlayed: so I wasn't expecting much from the story or gameplay. As it turns out the gameplay was really good; the controls were nice and tight
voteText: even when you drive vehicles. Even flying a VTOL (those flying things that work like helicopters) and floating around in zero-gravity was intuitive
helpfulPercent: which is saying a lot.\n\nAlthough Crysis is obviously a linear game
votesHelpful: the map was usually open enough that as long as you are going in the general direction of your next objective (which is what your character
votesTotal: Nomad
votesFunny: would be doing anyway) you won't feel constrained at all.\n\nThe one area where gameplay suffered was the enemy AI. I found them laughably stupid
commentsCount: and took great sadistic pleasure in luring large numbers of them into small choke points where I could easily mow them down.\n\nOn the opposite end of the spectrum
column16: there were a couple of areas where I really wasn't given sufficient tools to complete the objectives. One example was a map where I was trying to destroy a few anti-aircraft emplacements. I ended up having two enemy helicopters following me around
column17: and I only found one rocket launcher on the entire map. It was a pretty open map so I may have missed the others
column18: but they weren't in any of the obvious places. So I ended up just running around cloaked as much as possible until I managed to complete my objective. Oh
column19: and once that was complete the helicopters magically went away.\n\nThe nano suit is the biggest aspect of the game (besides the graphics) that differentiates Crysis from other military shooters. The suit allows you to choose between several modes: strength
column22:
and cloak. Thanks to the nano suit you can play the game using a variety of play styles. One of my favorite things to do was to sneak into a complex cloaked dual-wielding a couple of silenced pistols with laser sights. It then became a nice little exercise in shooting everyone in the head one at a time before they figured out that I was there (and given that the AI was so stupid they would only figure out that I was there if they got a nice long look at me while uncloaked.) Ninja Nomad.

The story can be summed up pretty quickly: North Koreans and aliens on a tropical island.

Once you know that
column23: nothing will surprise you. There were no plot twists
column24: no sudden betrayals or finding out someone was a double agent or anything. But I was fine with that
column25: because that wasn't why I was there anyway. That being said
column26: I did like the ending; it was a satisfying "hell yeah!" at the end of a nice ten-hour campaign.\n\nIf you are at all interested in playing Crysis
column27: now is the best time to do it. The game is old enough that it is really cheap but it is still new enough to look good."

reviewText: What a major step up this game was from the original far cry. A lot of people give this game sh*t for just being a tech demo but i do genuinely believe that this is a good game behind the sh*tty optimisation and being a pain in the asss to get it running on windows 64 bit. This game has a lot of awesome and memorable sequences and most of them  were not scripted at all its all because of the way i played the game so you're enjoyment level is very subjective by how you play it. I don't remember the game being this short though, only 7 hours i thought it was much longer and i didn't feel like i rushed through the game at all. A big complaint about the game is the aliens in the second half. The zero gravity mission is awful ill say that but actually fighting the aliens was alot of fun for me, i really like the shooting and the cloaking. I don't understand the hate, the game would have been boring if you were fighting koreans throughout the whole thing. If you don't mind spending some time to get the game working on windows 64 then go ahead and play it.\n7/10 (Good)

reviewText: Much along the lines of Half-life with graphics that were way ahead of it's time, even today it demands a powerful card to run it at it's best.  Interaction with the real world is unparalleled. The initial opening of the game is really excellent. With the ability to wander all over the place, the gave feels very open, but unfortunately as it progresses it feels more and more scripted and linear. This is also reflected in the load it puts on your graphics card, which decreases as you go along. Unfortunately the final stages of the game rather bugged, and the final boss is confusing to say the least. Amazing that they haven't sorted these problems. However, despite all the problems, it is still a remarkable game, and one you just have to have!

reviewText:
This game is great fun and I thoroughly recommend it. The shooting is smooth as silk and the addition of the suit powers is awesome, really makes you feel like a bad ♥♥♥, at least at the beginning. I found the combat engaging and diverse.

It may not be particularly long but what you do get out of it is great. From start to finish it is a thrill ride of explosions, shootouts and alien invasions. It’s not a bad looker either, also with the huge open levels it feels a lot more expansive than a normal FPS. The many animals, realistic island and beautiful sunsets and rises really add depth to the world.

Buy Today and don’t delay. Have Fun ^_^

reviewText:
If you're planning on Playing a shooter that is 9 years old this game is amazing in all the shooter aspects.
And It's not entirely shooting your way in, tactical and stealth gameplay also is a big part of the game.

First of all this game does a very beautiful environment, a really big forest and great foliage density makes the stealth approash really easy and more realistic and the way you interact with any plant is very real.

The graphics for the time of release are the best for any shooter game and for now It's really good easily playable.

It has a nice gameplay, you have a suit with four features on it, you can either have it cloacked or get you more strength or more armor or more speed and you can choose your weapons attachments the way you're planning to do your mission, and there is multiple routes and multiple ways to tackle your objectives it is kinda open world game, you can drive land, sea and air vehicles and the controls are really really good as well as the damage system on the vehicles is very realistic. Another thing to mention is the weapon animation they give it a slight movement when you move or aim so it feels real and there is a nice recoil system so you cant just spray.

The story is spot on, it is very well told,it is very well executed, it doesnt lack action and shooting at all and it is interesting.

The multiplayer for this game was powered by gamespy and since they stopped it, online is not available for this game but I saw a website that allows you to re play online in some way so you can check that out if youre interested in the online aspect of the game.

Overall it was was a great experience I loved this game and moving on to the second installment of It.

reviewText:
A sci-fi military action adventure masterpiece.

State of the art, cutting edge PC graphics and gameplay. This game... makes others feel lifeless and boring. Crysis is a true living breathing world that set the bar of how all first person shooter's should be.

Ever since 2007 of it's release many games have been emulating this graphical achievement. It's a simple yet effective story with ground breaking gameplay that set the bar for future games. This game takes you on a true action adventure that feels like Terminator 2 that meets Predator.

10/10

reviewText:
I love the Crysis series. Regardless of what many may think about it i find it very entertaining with diverse ways to play. It sucks that from what i hear is that they're shutting down their online servers, in which case i hope steam will step in and fix the online.

So basically you're a super soldier, you have many different abilities that you can use to your advantage. Whether that is super speed, stealth, super strength, or armor. This game has a bit more of an open world compared to Crysis 2. Unfortunately i haven't played 3 yet, but i will at some point to get more of the story. This game is worth what the price is for the single player. I would however wait for a sale with a bundle together for it. Get them all at once for cheap :P

Anyways i would love to get more into this game and tell you about the story, but i think i'll just let the game speak for itself. Enjoy one of the most graphically astounding games of it's time and have fun in one of the most fun games i ever played. :)

(fyi i played this on ps3 a bit more than the steam version)

reviewText:
As a newer PC gamer that never had the chance to play Crysis when it was released, I find the game to hold up better than all of the other Crysis games.

The game feels like a PC game and not some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port. The game treats itself seriously and allows you to tackle challenges in anyway you want

Pros
-Nanosuit changes on command to Stealth mode, Strength mode, Speed mode, and Defense Mode
-Guns feel realistic powerful
-Enemy AI is smart and will respond to your actions intelligently, which requires great awareness to overcome
-Huge World
-Graphics definetely hold up to this day, even for a game made almost a decade ago
-Modability allows for even greater longevity
-You feel like you are in control of every situation and are not limited to some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mechanic
-You can hold MULTIPLE WEAPONS. Not just limited to TWO. A pistol, 2 primaries, and explosives.

Cons-
-Game story feels kind of similar to the original Halo's story
-(this may be a individual issue) but I have issues running this game in 64 bit, with a gtx 980 and an amd fx8350. Doesn't make sense.
-Can be confusing at times

Overall this game is great, and a must own for any PC gamer.

reviewText:
If you are a sci-fi fan and also love FPS games, then this is definitely the game for you. Crysis is a game full of action, super awesome graphics (made with cryengine technology), brilliant textures, particles, shadows and physics, very interesting plot, satisfying length, nice weapons and weapon attachement-upgrades. cons: the game has a few bugs and looks heavy, if you wanna enjoy the graphics fully, you need a strong graphics card..

PS: the game supports multiplayer and also inporting game mods (some of which are veeery cool)!

reviewText: Don't expect a plot beyond your generic Sci-fi stuff. The gameplay, however, is still incredibly fun, and offers so many options that every encounter can be different. Your Nanosuit has four abilities, and the use of each one drains your suit's Energy bar. Fortunately it, as well as your health, regenerate in a decent pace to allow quick, exciting and varied combat sessions. Combined with cars and boats, as well as fairly open level designs, each fight in Crysis can be a fresh experience unlike many other shooters.\n\nYour armor has Speed" to dart around the battlefield and rush up to enemies to knock them down. "Strength" for stronger melee
date: as well as high jumps (one of the favorite fights in my playthrough was using this to jump over a fence into an enemy base
recommended: and then run around their rooftops
hoursPlayed: hopping from one to the other and gunning them down as I go). "Armor" to absorb damage and hasten the recovery of Energy and Health. And lastly
voteText: "Invisibility". The stealth aspect of the game isn't as refined as it could be - silent takedowns aren't too silent and you can't hide bodies - but still enjoyable.\n\nWeapons are also modifiable to a small degree with different attachments

reviewText:
Well, I did not expect something published by EA was so good until I tried it.

Before I start the game, some issue happened like crashed and stuff. Those are not bugs, but compatibility issueS.

Nice mechanics, I like how you can choose between modes in your nano suit. Most of all, the gun customization is the best ♥♥♥♥ in this game. Who doesn't like laser scope. It's not entirely linear, the stage is so big that you can run all over the place, which is quite redundant. You can drive vehicles like Hum-Vee, Tanks, cars, boats and VTOL

The graphics is gorgeous, extremely beautiful. I can't wait to wear play this game in VR.

The campaign is quite long, at least is longer than I expected.

I need to whine about the lack of tutorial in this game, the Rifle Grenade Launcher's mechanics is so confusing that I didn't have a chance to use. So you better try to get hold to every mechanics in the game before you got serious.

Well, the A.I is not that smart, I was playing in NORMAL mode and was using laser scope and cloaking around, pointed laser to Korean's face and he didn't react, A.I's IQ is as much as a typical North Korean.

NO BUG affected my gameplay. Smooooooth. The PC port was good.

The best of all NO Origins DRM.

Verdict: This is a gem, BUY please. 8/10

reviewText:
Crysis is notorious for having both the highest of high end graphics and for dishing out the most punishment to your computer hardware.  But in the two+ years since release it's become a lot easier to get the hardware necessary to play, and if you've got it you owe yourself the chance to see the visual glory Crysis offers.

Crysis is more than a pretty picture though; the game offers some deft gun combat that's mixed in with many opportunities to be sneaky thanks to your special powers. The vehicles however are unsatisfying to drive and the energy meter for your powers feels anemic. Fortunately the weapons you have at your disposal offer a pleasing punch allowing you to make good progress in the single player without feeling much frustration.

Storywise the game strives for believability, but it's all balderdash play acting that undermines the serious aura.  Thankfully the free-flow pacing of the game gives you ample time to breath, explore, and appreciate the visuals.

reviewText: One of the biggest reason to be a PC gamer back in 2007. With it's revolutionary graphics, and a great singleplayer, Crysis is as good as it got when it came to sandbox shooters. The graphics still hold up 7 years later and even still look better than most modern games, which is quite unheard of in video games. The Nanosuit really gives the game a different take on shooters than all the other ones out there, in a really good way. As much greatness the Crysis series has brought with it though, it brought along plenty of disappointment as well with the series getting completely butchered with Crysis 2 and Crysis 3. When it comes to Crysis, Crysis 1 and Crysis Warhead are amazing games and some of the best shooters I've played and still worth playing if you missed out on it back in the day.

reviewText:
Crysis is something else: stunning graphics, an underused setting, an epic story, and an enjoyable multiplayer game to boot. People playing this will likely recall FarCry, with good reason. Crysis is the evolution of that title, using a new engine, but keeping the general feel of a 'hell in paradise'.

It all begins with what looks to be like a simple rescue mission. You and your group, equipped with the latest in nano-augmented suit technology, parachute into North-Korean-occupied territory to find an archaeologist. It should be a simple rescue mission, but something is definitely wrong, and as you continue through the island you've been dropped into, you'll find that there are more players in this game than you think.

The action in the single-player experience is as intensive as you want to make it. Your nano-suit grants you a variety of abilities, each of which augment what you can do and, depending on your use, how you play. You can increase your strength, adding damage to your attacks and allowing you to jump a dozen feet in the air; you can increase your speed, allowing you to run blindingly around your opponents; you can increase your armor, allowing your suit energy to take damage until it runs out and you start to bleed; or you can enter cloak mode, arguably one of the most useful suit abilities, which makes you invisible for a short time, allowing you to sneak around your opponents and confront them on your own terms.

Running into the fray, guns blazing, is always an option but a difficult one. It doesn't take a lot to bring you down, and when you have at least half a dozen enemies gunning for you, things can get real deadly real quick. Hiding in the underbrush allows you to stay out of sight of enemies, which is crucial when lookout towers are scattered across the territory that you need to move through. The result is gameplay that tends to be tense at times, but at others sometimes just feels like the bushes are playing a game of hot-potato, and you're the potato.

The game offers some magnificent environments, a notable difference from the usual faire in its genre. Maps span kilometres, which is an impressive feat that allows the game to be played differently than just running through small corridors. Though visually stellar, the problem with the environments is that many of them consist only of a valley that makes you move in a straight line to get to your target, as opposed to the wide-open nature of others. These valleys are probably more open than most FPS games, but they're a stark contrast to other sections of the game, and feel all the more constrained because of it.

The presentation is pretty top-notch: great acting, great story, and a pace that keeps the action going throughout.The single player campaign may be fun, but it does end, and when it does, the multiplayer game is where you go to continue the action. Luckily, it delivers quite excellently.

Crysis has definitely raised the stakes when it comes to graphics, and is probably going to be used as a technical benchmark for many years to come. Its stunning environments and interesting gameplay that changes with the suit's powers create a very enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
Ahhh Crysis.

This was one of those games which totally got me back into PC gaming.
Yeah, some years I was actually quite frequently using a console but when this game came out...
DAMN. I loved it. I actually build my first rig back then. Myself, no prebuild crap. 8600GT and a Intel Pentium 4. Back then I wasnt spending much money for hardware. With that specs I was able to play the game on medium settings with playable FPS but that was it pretty much. In 1024x768. Gosh, couldnt even imagine myself playing like this anymore. Back then no hardware could run it playable with 30FPS on Very High. I guess my rig had like 10FPS, haha.
Also I was still using Windows XP so no DX10 for me back then, or 64Bit...
Many years there was the term, But can it run Crysis". Even today Crysis still serves as Benchmark.
But thats snow from yesterday as we Germans say
date:
so lets get into the review.

The story is about some US soldiers invading a island named Ling Shan. Their mission is to safe some people and uncover the secrets of the island. You are Nomad and belong to those soldiers. The island belongs to the Korean army and General Kyong is the leader of them. The US soldiers dont stay undercover for long and have to deal with the army and... something else. Something else is present on this island and while you do your journey through the island you are going to uncover this entity.

The game is a FPS. You have to pass through very big open world levels to reach your mission goals and progress in this game. While you are doing so
recommended: many soldiers and other things will attack you. Luckily you have a bunch of weapons AND the Nanosuit! The Nanosuit pretty much is the reason why this game sets itself apart from other generic FPS shooters. Its a armor with that you can be very strong
voteText: armored and even invisible. For a certain time until the energy has to recover. I love this feature about the game. Its so simple
helpfulPercent:
yet addicting. On your way you also often get the possibility of using vehicles. How you do certain goals is up to you. Go in guns blazing or stealth. On higher difficulties you should definitely try to stealth. The difficulty can be quite high at points. Especially when playing on something higher than normal.

The game is made by Crytek. One of my favorite developers of our time.
The game runs on the CryEngine 2 which
votesHelpful: similar to Far Cry in 2004
votesTotal: made a revolution in terms of graphics in videogames. Nothing could even mess with the CryEngine 2 back then. Not even the Unreal Engine 3 which came out around the same time and often was praised for its graphics. It even offered DX10 and 64Bit support. But the downside of this was that the engine was extremely taxing on PCs. Even top notch highend rigs couldnt handle the game on very high settings. I really loved the graphics
votesFunny: it was amazing to see what actually was possible. It really looked like RL.\nEven today the game still looks stunning and beautiful
commentsCount: even if the CryEngine 3 probably took its place as best looking engine. This was especially noticeable after Crysis 3 came out. Crysis 2 sadly didnt use its full potencial at launch. But this was addressed with patches and even Crysis 2 looked stunning after the patches. Still
column16: Crysis is unmatched for me in terms of gameplay and graphics. Also Crysis was not made for consoles
column17: unlike its other games. Therefore I guess Crysis was not limited to anything like level sizes. But its probably also the memories that I have with this game. Crysis 2 and 3 are also amazing games and I like to replay all of them from time to time

reviewText: I felt compelled to write this. I've been playing video games ever since the Nintendo entertainment system was released in 85. I'm in my 30s now and I did not have a PC that could run this game when it was released. I've played all the big AAA's on PC old and new but always overlook this one. I purchased Crisis 2 and Crisis 3 again overlooking this one it's too old I keep telling myself. Purchased it on this recent sale. Researched some mods Texter foliage lighting etc. Installed them hopped on and OMG what a game. Not only is it beautiful and I mean beautiful. It has amazing AI an awesome story. The immersion is through the roof. If you immerse yourself in the game enough with a headset on you almost think you're in a Rambo movie. It has the old school difficulty of days gone by. The amazing destruction beautiful visuals (with mods) that today's games cannot capture. Battlefield 4 Call of Duty Ghost Assassins creed black flag don't come close visually or technically. What an amazing game I have been missing out all of these years. Of course it's taken 30+ years to be able to afford a rig that can run this and all of its glory. This game truly is a masterpiece.

reviewText: Crysis is still a game hog on today's machines.  However, it's a must play for anyone that wants to feel like they have full control on how the game is played.  Do you want to go guns blazing?  Do you want to use stealth?  You get to choose how you can take on each mission.  However, the world is not as open as Far Cry was, it is much more linear.  The graphics are some of the best graphics still even by today's standard and the action is non-stop.  The story, however, isn't that great.  Luckily the visual/audio of this game make up for any loss.  The ability to configure your gun and the added skills that are part of the nano-suit add some RPG elements to a wonderful FPS experience.  Definitely a classic to be played by all fans of the genre.

reviewText:
Crysis is a Sci-Fi First Person Shooter.

About the Game:

You are an army man on a mission from a special task force with a suit, mabye this doesn't sound original but the gameplay is super.
What makes this game good if you look to the other FPS games ???
The suit... gives you power to ... run fast... jump high or be invisible.
You fight your way on a island and play how you want to play.
Be like Rambo or sneak like Sold Snake (Metal Gear Solid)
The games has a amazing story mode and makes the game worth buying and playing.

Game looks amazing and this was the first game in my life where I purchased a 300 euro video card just to play it.
I think a lot of people did the same or know what I'm talking about.
For me it was a new reason to spend a ♥♥♥♥ load of money on a core 2 duo or quad core pc.
Only now you can play the game with a basic GTX650 Ti or higher card,

Single Player:

Some parts of the game gives you the freedom to go everywhere you like to go.
The maps are gigantic and a lot of stiff to explore.
Some parts are pure rail shooters... you walk the way and try to defeat your enemies.
I think this game has not special story line only it's really great to play and experiance.
Not graphic part wil not be a problem for many VGA cards.
Yes most games will look better now on the day I made this review.
Still Crysis looks amazing and will give you a very good experience.
And will let you give a look in the story mode / world of Crysis.

MultiPlayer Option:

Crysis whas made as a single player demo and the multiplayer has not been updated after the Wars addon.
The Basic crysis had only deathmatch and power struggle.
Deathmatch is free for all and power strungle is more like a capture the points and earn money to buy new weapons.
So this multiplayer is extreme basic as it can be only funny thing is.
This whas one of the best multiplayer games i've been played after all these years.
Yes it is basic... but freaking good !!
Just basic FPS multiplayer fun for LAN or to play with friends online.
Everybody has the same suits... no upgrades.. and there are weapons to find and pick up.
I had so much fun with this game in LAN parties
Played it for more than 500 hours and enjoyed every hour.
When I noticed that the game was on sale on Steam for a few euros I bought it right away.

Overall:

I think this is a must have game for every FPS fan.
Epic Game, Good Story, Basic Multiplayer and has a small history if you ask me.
That's why I give it a 9/10 score.

reviewText:
The graphics are the most substantial part of this game. Anything else, you can consider it broken.

Enemies become virtually omnipotent whenever they're on a mounted gun, with an unlimited spotting distance. Helicopters don't even need to see you to know where to fire their one-hit-kill missiles. One wrong step on a piece of debris can instantly end you. The AI can easily break in multiple ways, making them either completely vegetative or nearly unstoppable. Weapons can glitch out and disappear at any time.

In fact, there is so much wrong with this game that not even the good bugs, the entertaining ones, can make up for it. This is a sign of pure incompetence, a failure to grasp multiple important concepts of game design. You don't need to look bad to play bad. You can scuplt a Michelangelo piece out of faeces, but what do you still have?

Crysis. That's what. Don't waste your time unless you're just out to prove your PC's power.

reviewText:
Brilliant FPS that keeps you attached. Insane graphics and gameplay. Story takes a few wild turns, starting off as a typical military super soldier game to a crazy alien fight, run for your life situation.

Nomad isn't much of a protagonist, but he progresses as one of the most important characters in the Crysis universe for being a sort of first contact with the alien epidemic.

As for the game, it's Crytek, and while their stories are the most polished, their games are the most polished. The graphics at the time in 2007 were meanth to run on machines and graphics cards that didn't exist yet, so it was obvious that this title, and the devs wwere ahead of its' time.

9.2/10

reviewText:
Maximum everything

CRYSIS is an exceptional game in many respects. Firstly, and most famously, it looks absolutely stunning. On maximum settings the island on which the adventure takes place truly comes to life. The quality of the graphics and the physics remain unsurpassed, in my opinion, even when compared to more recent games. Immersion is critical in games such as this and the CryENGINE used provides this in spades. There’s also a pretty good storyline behind the action and the pacing is good, with the action steadily ramping up to an impressive big finale. The voice acting is always convincing and the cut-scenes fit seamlessly into the flow of the game. The combat is challenging and rewarding. I have just two criticisms: First is the fact that the single player game ends! I wanted much more but this is a game that can be played more than once as the “sandbox” nature of the island allows for different approaches to the gameplay, plus there’s a good multiplayer version to continue the fun, and there are custom maps and mods out there. Second, there’s not enough humour. I think any game benefits from a few laughs (the Half-Life series is an excellent example) but I can’t remember any in CRYSIS. Still, this doesn’t matter too much when what you’re given is so absorbing and entertaining.

5/5
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Crysis is what machines used to cry on. The beautiful details are even more accessable to the market now that hardware has caught up. Anything built for gaming these days (be it budget or not) should be able to have no problems running this spiritual successor to Far Cry.

Gameplay is smooth and allows you to consider just how you want to approach your target; by foot, sea, air, or car. You can use your suit's capabilities to give you that edge from acting as it's default armor, to improving movement speeds (which due to the open environment is very useful), to keeping you fully cloaked.

Story-wise, it isn't very appealing, but overall the game in itself is something any PC Gamer should have a go at, if just for their history.

reviewText:
Regardless of the date of production of this title, it gets a solid 10/10 for being polished.  That said, it was ahead of its time, and I beleive has had an impact on the industry and customer satisfaction even across genres due to the hardware driven nature of this title.

Even if you do not delve into the hardware and system tweaking discussions that can be evoked by even mentioning the name Crysis at all, you are left with a great game conceptually and artistically.

The story-telling and voice/character acting are very seamless, and all the entire architecture of the game design is cohesive.  I was pleasently surprised to see the game evolve from remote island views to frozen SCI-FI worlds that are revealed in a manner that is very enthralling.  The plot and enemy design are the best things about this game to me, and they are why I think it is hard to put this game down even years after its debut (although the graphics are what made me interested in the game to begin with).

Unfortunately, it has taken all those years since its release for me to fully appreciate and realize this, as I could not get to the interesting parts without system lags interfering with the enjoyable quality of the game.  I found the game hard to enjoy at 15FPS, and I think anyone who has played this game on maximum settings without frame drops would not trade the experience.

When Crysis came out, you would be lucky to get 30FPS on maxed out settings on a medium-high end PC.  This probably is no longer the case and you can enjoy what was at the time about the closest thing to being in control of an interactive movie on your system.

This game continues to push hardware limits, and today is probably much more accessible to the average gamer than it was when it was first released and barely playable without spending a mere fortune.  The graphics are just as stunning as the physics, and the CRY-engine is polished but can be laggy at times compared to more light-weight games (depending on your system specifications).  The most optimized platforms at max settings continue to respect real-world dynamics and rigid body interactions/physics in a more satisfying manner than most competitive games/engines do with respect to fluid/solid body motions and raycasting/tracing in my opinion.

I did find the environments and modeling of terrain to be more photorealistic in Crysis 1 as compared to its sequel; however, my system still has trouble handling the DX-11 patches for Crysis-2 on max settings on HD6990 Radeon and IntelX990.  This game is fun just because it is hard to talk about it without discussing the hardware and graphics, but I do think the animation style, branding and abundance of environmental details are what carried this game into public visibility and have secured it a place in videogame history.  At the end of the day, it is a beautiful game with extreme longevity with regards to its visual presentation.

reviewText:
A schizophrenic gameplay experience that can't decide what it wants to be, punishing the player for taking one role for more than 10 seconds at a time, even a well designed engine with such potential for tweaking and customisation can't save this game and it's trite, overdone, and lackluster story.

While you can easily see where the influence of this game came from, I am going to complete this review without any reference to Halo. The most notable detail, one that you'll see as soon as you begin playing, is the scenery. The aesthetically pleasing environment of this FPS puts all others to shame. However, while the levels seem quite open and non-linear at a glance, they feel limited.

The numbers in this game need a serious overhaul and a definite position on whether or not it's a stealth game, a cover-based shooter, or a terminator versus the horde game.
