reviewText:
As I played this game from 2007 in 2014, all graphics settings could be maxed out. I was amazed that a 7 year old game, could deliver such an enjoyable experience! Especially as FPS tend to depend alot on their graphics performance. Crysis provided a good mix of stealth, full-on action, vehicular combat and differing environments. Although not as open as some of  the more recent FPS games (e.g. Far Cry 3), it provides ample opportunities to choose different paths in reaching your objectives. The nanosuit deserves a special mention as it adds gameplay due to the capabilities of the suit. Overall, a highly recommended golden classic!

Score: 8.5/10

Pro:
+ very nice graphics (even if the game is almost 7 years old!)
+ nanosuit capabilities
+ excellent gameplay
+ semi-open world
+ decent amount of mods available on the internet (didn't try any)

Contra:
- too short; 10 to 15 hours to complete
- some enemy A.I. & graphics glitches
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I remember when this was considered a trial by fire for anyone's computer, even today some low end rigs struggle to run it.

It's a nice game, perhaps set back by it's stiffy for post-processing, but there's a functional experience here at least, it annoyed me that the multiplayer didn't have vehicles, that was introduced in Crysis Warhead.

Aaaaanyway, Crysis begins when your squad is sent to the Lingshan islands to rescue a research team who have uncovered something big, and dangerous. Ancient technology of an alien civilization buried in the earth.

And now I'm sitting in the same pose as that History Channel bloke, ALIENS.

Outside of combatting an awakening alien scourge, you fight against a division of the Korean Military who have occupied the island due to the discovery, using stealth, wits, various vehicles, and your Nanosuit to overcome the challenges facing you.

The game also features a realtime weapon modification mechanic, allowing you to swap out attachments and ammo types on the fly, you unlock these attachments as you find them ingame, my personal recommendation is to use an assault scope and a silencer on your FY-71, and then keep a Precision Rifle with a Sniper scope handy for those crucial shots.

I will not spoil any of the game's major plot points, play it for yourself if you are interested.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is still one of the best looking games available. I'm not someone to buy a game just because the graphics look nice but this is a must own for anyone that can appreciate detail and great level design. The giant island sandbox, mixed with highly destructible environments makes this game shine. There's nothing like getting on a heavy machine gun turrent, mowing down everyone in front of you while trees are being cut down, dirt chunks are flying into the air and small shacks are getting destroyed crumbling into pieces. Or throwing a grenade into a small village full of enemies and watching sheet metal fly, walls being blown apart while enemies fly into them.

The games only downfall is it starts out very slow, but just stick with it, the more you progress the more the game throws at you and you'll be in some great fire fights.

If you have this game (and played it very little) or want to buy it do yourself a favor and download Tactical Expansion Mod V1.1. This mod is a must while playing this game. Adds better blood effects, ramps up the AI, and adds a ton of new weapons and attachments.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
There's a great sense of empowerment by running through a jungle stealthed up to an enemy base, turning off your cloak and turning on your armour and systematically taking out every enemy in that base as your rifle carefully guides you to your target. The fact that that's just one way of many to go about your objectives is one of the reasons it's a great game.

Crysis' strengths are numerous. Gun-play feels satisfying, both the actual shooting of enemies as well as the feedback of toying around with attachments, to the extent that if you played the game as a straight shooter, you probably wouldn't be disappointed. That the movement options available to you wide and varied, from the slow and stealthy approach to the super fast leaping-and-bounding traversal. That you can approach an encounter in a myriad of ways, some because it will be more effective and some because it'll just be plain fun. That these are all wrapped up in a gorgeous visual presentation and audio that gives weight to your movement and minute-to-minute actions is just an icing on an already yummy cake.

Really though it's the freedom of the game to let you do things the way you want to that is its strongest aspect, clearly in exchange for a hum-drum plot that, whilst a little awkward, changes tone and direction in the second half to something that is at least a little more engaging. That each objective is punctuated by an open enviroment with traversal allowing you to explore the islands you operate on with no real time limit gives the game a much bigger scope than simply moving from one fire-fight to the next, preventing any sense of boredom creeping in, but ultimately it's down to you to keep things as entertaining as you want them to be. So yes, again, you could just shoot your way through everything, but perhaps you'll strap some explosives to a truck, drive up to a base stealthed, dive out of the car at the last moment and watching the vehicle explode and the base erupt into chaos as you sleuth around it to eliminate any opposition. Or maybe you'll just zoom around at maximum speed punching your targets and sending them flying into walls. It's your choice.

Whilst the freedom in play is reduced in the second half of the game with the plot's directional change, the feeling of the hunter is swapped around and instead of using your suit's powers for offensive actions, you're using them to survive in any manner you seem most suitable. With a pace that's consistent and overall length that is neither too short nor overstays its welcome as well as proving as much replayability as you have creativity, Crysis is a great first person shooter with a high quota for enjoyment.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying Crysis is a very different game to what I expected.  Boy was I wrong and I am GLAD for it. I was expecting to step into the shoes of a Master Chief style tank/super soldier that could Clint Eastwood his way through the fight. Crysis instead puts you into the shoes of an American Special Forces soldier and asks you to think like one. It was VERY refreshing and VERY welcome. The Nano Suit (think super soldier suit) which you wear doesn't make you an invincible force of nature but instead makes you feel like you are wearing a USEFUL military designed peice of hardware. It expands the natural abilities that a special forces soldier would need and use, not grant him super powers. The suit merely gives you options to tackle any situation how you see fit and THAT is what makes this game clever.

I also want to put on record that I know and understand that the Crysis series is designed to break computers. I played this game on Maximum settings as intended and it is FREAKING GORGEOUS. A game that came out in 2007 still beats out most modern day titles that I have seen in 2014. It is wonderful to be awed by the graphics of a game to this extent and I am blessed to own a computer that could handle it easily (although I do feel that this would be a sticking point for many players with underpowered hardware). Just because my experience was great, doesn't mean your experience will be. Please understand that your milage could vary from my review!

So I finished the game in 12 hours (which is leaning on the shorter side)  but the story and the pacing complimented this length nicely so it is hard to chalk this as adrawback. I also played with a gamepad (Xbox 360) but it is easy to tell that Crysis is designed with the Keyboard and Mouse in mind. It works don't get me wrong! But it isn't always natural.

So in conclusion I HIGHLY recommend Crysis. It is smarter than it appears.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: What is there to say about Crysis that has not already been said. It is a georgeous masterpiece that looks amazing and stands the test of time. When this game came out in 2007 I can assure you that almost nobody had a powerful enough machine to run this game maxed out. As much as I could say about the graphics it is more than just a tech demo and is an amazing game in just about every other aspect. The game takes place in the year 2020 were you play as a nano-suited supersoldier named Nomad. This suit has many features such as cloak mode, armour mode, strength made, and speed mode. It can also help the user survive in extreme cold and heat. You are sent to the Korean controlled Lingshan Islands when you recieve a distress signal from a scientist named Rosenthal. As you continue your mission members of your team start to die in weird ways and things get stranger and stranger. Little does the team know that their suits have awakened an alien race hidden in the island. I won't spoil the ending because this is a game that you should play for yourself. The gameplay of Crysis is quite fun. This FPS puts you on the island and it is huge and allows you to choose your own path to the next objective. Do you sneak in through the woods and make it undetected or storm in in an armored car. The choice is yours. As for the weapons there are several modern and futeristic weapons ranging from sub-machine guns, assault rifles, sniper rifles, pistols, shotguns, rocket launchers, modified alien mini turrets, and even your own fists. As for multiplayer there are two main modes. There is a standard deathmatch mode and then there is the power struggle mode. In power struggle there are two teams, each with their own main base. The point of the game is to capture smaller command points and to kill members of the other team until you have enough money to get a really powerful weapon to take out the enemy's main base and win the game. going back to graphics there are some more things to talk about. The game came out right around when windows vista came out and supposedly can take advantage of its features. Mainly it can run in DX10 mode although it was mainly built around DX9. You normally can't acces very high settings on DX9 so windows xp users would be out of luck but there are two ways around this. The first is to go into the configuraton file and edit it to force very high settings on DX9 wich looks almost exactly the same as on DX10 with the only difference being some subtle lighting effects only on DX10. The other way is to get a version of DX10 that will run on windows xp that was released a year or two ago, go to the files for Crysis and change the name of the file called D3D9 to D3D10 and then change D3D10 to D3D9, and then to go into the lauch options on Steam and type in this line  -DX10". This will allow you to run Crysis on the highest settings in DX10 mode on windows xp. This game is more than worth the 20 dollars it costs to get. I hope this review was helpful and that you enjoy this masterpiece as much as I have."

reviewText:
Crysis is what machines used to cry on. The beautiful details are even more accessable to the market now that hardware has caught up. Anything built for gaming these days (be it budget or not) should be able to have no problems running this spiritual successor to Far Cry.

Gameplay is smooth and allows you to consider just how you want to approach your target; by foot, sea, air, or car. You can use your suit's capabilities to give you that edge from acting as it's default armor, to improving movement speeds (which due to the open environment is very useful), to keeping you fully cloaked.

Story-wise, it isn't very appealing, but overall the game in itself is something any PC Gamer should have a go at, if just for their history.

I seriously need to put more hours into this game, because I can give you three reasons why to pick up this game.

1.First thing you'll notice is the graphics, for a game that came out in 2007, it looks absolutely gorgeous, one of the best looking games on the pc, whether it's the facial animation or the lush forests, it's beautiful.

3.The story is excellent here, now while I haven't gotten too far in the story, I've gotten to the point where it's actually starting to grip me, making me want to fight in the battles that occur later on, it gets extremely emotional.

There you have it, Crysis is an extremely well developed first person shooter and I could recommend it to anyone, not to mention that along with the campaign we also get a multiplayer. I give it a 9/10.

reviewText:
In 2007 Turkish-German game developer Crytek released ‘Crysis’, a cryengine-built first person shooter which exceeded the graphical norm at the time more than any other game ever did or would later do. Almost no computer could run it at the time and for many years it would be the ideal game to test new gaming PC’s with, but even disregarding this main strength of the game Crysis is a very decent FPS.
In Crysis you take the role of an American soldier named ‘Nomad’ who is part of an elite squadron of nanosuit-equipped soldiers . You are sent to the Lingshan islands in the pacific to rescue a team of archeologists from North-Korean soldiers who took the place over. Story is not quite the part of the game that deserves closest examination because of that it is quite generic. After all, even back in 2007 there were already quite a few games that had the player kill soldiers while playing as an American soldier himself, but luckily the story takes a bit of a back seat here. It would not be until Crysis 2 that other things than combat would be given some attention. In terms of story delivery there is also nothing new here.
What you would want to play Crysis for, if not the superb graphics, would be its gameplay and it does this quite well. Although it uses pretty standard FPS mechanisms the nanosuit makes for a welcome addition. Basically the suit gives you a choice of four superpowers, which consume from one general energy bar. There is a speed mode, pretty self-explanatory, a cloak mode that makes you largely invisible, a power mode that lets you jump higher and fling heavy objects and an armour mode. Using whatever improvements your power gives you costs energy and generally this system holds up pretty well. It is nice that you are given the choice between stealthing a section with the cloak or fighting through it normally, and if you choose the latter you can also pick different tactics with either the speed or the armour mode.  A nice small addition on the side is that you are at any time able to modify your weapon, which means you can pick your sight, add a suppressor or make other small modifications.
The game also excels in giving the player freedom. Before Crytek set about on making Crysis they made the original Far Cry. Why these developers are so attached to the word ‘cry’ remains a mystery. But anyway, Far Cry was an open world game which was, like Crysis, set on a tropical island and sometimes it seems as if the developers carved a big and wide linear path out of Far Cry’s sandbox to make Crysis because Crysis feels about as unlinear as a linear game can be. The entire game has a structure similar to Half Life 2, in that you are never teleported to a different location but always go there yourself. There are almost no missions that all of a sudden take place somewhere else unless the last mission had you go there by yourself. Some objectives give you entire towns to play around in, a lot of the houses can be smashed up and most objects can be grabbed and thrown as weapons. What also makes this game feel like some fenced-off sandbox is the completely free use of vechiles. When you need to go to the next firefight you can walk there if you want, or you can get in a car which the game just puts outside most villages. Driving mechanics are not very good though, so if you are being shot at you are in more danger in a car than on foot.
Although Crysis is indeed a very good FPS it does have a few minor issues I want to mention. Firstly that would be the story. I understand that a game like this leaves little room for something outrageously good, but they could perhaps have done a little less effort to make the North-Koreans look like jerks because in a game based around so much military excessive force, as showcased in a level where you take part in a big tank offensive, making the enemy seem evil just puts the entire game in a big cliché. Of course in a game with such a simple story you want to have your side as the goodies and the other side to be the baddies, but emphasizing that so much makes it all feel a bit fake. Some enemies come across as silly cartoon villains. My other nibbles mostly restrict to specific sections and mentioning them spoils parts of the game for you, so be warned about the following part. What peeved me a bit about one level that takes place in an alien space ship was that the entire place is extremely disorienting. Although that bit still looks extremely gorgeous graphics-wise, I found myself moving through the same looped corridor about five times before I found the right way by accident and the beauty loses something if it is forced upon you for so long. Another annoying part was one section where your squadmate, ‘Prophet’, has a damaged nanosuit which means you have to escort him and bring him to some kind of heat source every few seconds to prevent him from dying. It is not even hard at all and the combat is not harder with him around, so the entire thing just feels like a silly delay.  On the side, I found the game’s soundtrack to be very unimaginative. It does nothing to increase the atmosphere.
So, in conclusion I would certainly recommend Crysis, even today. Although the graphics don’t excel anymore and the story is pretty rubbish, the gameplay is still very nice and you have plenty of liberty to explore the nanosuits potential, and that certainly outweighs the game’s few issues.

reviewText:
Just to get it out of the way: yes, this game is gorgeous, one of the best looking of all time and it still is today. However, I've never been particularly a good graphics kind of gamer, I'm more about the gameplay in games. Luckily, the gameplay in Crysis is a lot of fun. The thing that really makes it is the nanosuit, giving you four different abilities to use: speed, strength, armour, and invisibility. Mixing and matching these four modes is a lot of fun, and allows for a lot of experimentation during combat. Stealth is also a crucial strategy, especially when there are dozens of enemies you have to eliminate. The enemy AI is very good as well, it works very well with stealth and during combat they will try to flank you. Add in the different weapon customizations, there are a lot of combinations to use in enemy encounters that it will keep you entertained for the duration of the campaign. The level design is also nice and open, giving you even more options like sniping and using vehicles.

The story in the game isn't particularly good, but this isn't the kind of game you play for the story, you should play it for the gameplay and graphics. However, where the game really faulters, is in the last two or two-and-a-half hours of the campaign when you start battling the aliens. The aliens just aren't as fun to fight as the Koreans and don't allow for much variation in the ways you want to fight them.

Crysis is a great game, particularly is you like experimentation in the ways you want to handle the enemy encounters.  Half the fun is just seeing what kind of stuff you can get away with, and I love that.

reviewText:
Maximum everything

CRYSIS is an exceptional game in many respects. Firstly, and most famously, it looks absolutely stunning. On maximum settings the island on which the adventure takes place truly comes to life. The quality of the graphics and the physics remain unsurpassed, in my opinion, even when compared to more recent games. Immersion is critical in games such as this and the CryENGINE used provides this in spades. There’s also a pretty good storyline behind the action and the pacing is good, with the action steadily ramping up to an impressive big finale. The voice acting is always convincing and the cut-scenes fit seamlessly into the flow of the game. The combat is challenging and rewarding. I have just two criticisms: First is the fact that the single player game ends! I wanted much more but this is a game that can be played more than once as the “sandbox” nature of the island allows for different approaches to the gameplay, plus there’s a good multiplayer version to continue the fun, and there are custom maps and mods out there. Second, there’s not enough humour. I think any game benefits from a few laughs (the Half-Life series is an excellent example) but I can’t remember any in CRYSIS. Still, this doesn’t matter too much when what you’re given is so absorbing and entertaining.

5/5

reviewText: There's something special about this game and Crysis Warhead that the rest of the series missed the mark on. I'd like to say I can't quite place it, but I can indeed, and it saddens me: Choices. Not choices in the sense of determining who lives and dies, for those are typically semilinear in nature. Choices as in how to get from A to B, as the game places you in a large sandbox environment where the objective is to traverse from one end to the other. And while it very slowly begins to show some age, Crysis remains a beautiful and oddly invigorating game compared to many other FPS games I've played as of late.

reviewText:
I have to go out on a limb here and say that this is actually one of the best FPS games I ever played, period.

Others may point out the deficiencies, but through the curious way I experienced this game it has ultimately assumed the status of an absolute classic in my eyes.

That experience I mention is this: On my first ever playthrough, my rig was such that the game crashed as soon as I entered the final act - all that water and all those explosions, you dig? - and so I never actually knew that it was the final act. In my mind the game stretched on into inifinity - and what an infinity it was.

The game goes through three distinct phases, each more jaw-droppingly perfect than the last. At first, one is navigating a jungly-coated tropical island world, evading - or annihilating, though this was never as fun for me - conventional, dastardly Korean forces in a manner strongly remeniscent of the original Far Cry (for me at least, Far Cry didn't really have any stealth component, though i did everything i could to force it to play like a stealth shooter nonetheless) In the second phase, all-out conflict has broken out and, while you can continue to play as a phantom if you wish, the stakes and scale soar upwards into 'epic' territory. In the third phase, you discover a vast and fantastic secret lurking within the island, exploring this secret in a state of permawonder, before re-emerging into a drastically altered form of the second phase, to see out the game.

My initial experience was cut short most of the way through the third phase, so in my mind it was, as I've said, neverending, and by jebus that neverending game was FPS fantasy made reality. It really is just an awesome game.

Quite apart form the graphics, which are to this day superior to almost any other offering of comprable setting (visually if not technolgically, though the tech is still close), the gameplay is tight and perfectly polished. This is the kind of game that, while vaguely linear, allows a player to turn 100m of linear progression into around 1km of side-track meandering and sneaking more or less throughout the entire experience. One can craft one's own adventure here, as surely as any of those gimmicky kids books from the '90s, and just as everyone had envisioned in their wildest dreams back then this adventure is lush, endless and full of wonders more wonderous than the last.

The gameplay is consistent and with the possible exception of the final moments of the second phase, in which combat is more or less forced on you and the game literally ejects any background action in an effort - only marginally succesful - to turn your final stage into some kind of arena, it is consistently entertaining.

Why should you buy this game? Because your computer may very well finally be able to run it in something approaching max settings, because it is one of the best FPS experiences you will ever play, and because it is streets, miles ahead of any other similar game released in the years before or the years after.

reviewText:
One of the best games ever created in 2007. The graphics are just amazing. It's a must for FPS lovers.  Also, they have my respect for making the game PC exclusive.

Don't get me wrong though, it is a very enjoyable shooter that I recommend for all you have the PC requirements to play it. It may not be remembered for as long as the popular console games, but it is one of the best on PC and should definitely be on your shopping list.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I like to keep my reviews short and simple so I'll just tell you what you need to hear to decide on buying this game.

Graphics: 6/10 (It's an oldish game, but for it's time would of been good)

Gameplay: 9/10 (It's a bit duck and shoot but you can use trucks/etc and of course the nano-suit which is very tactical)

Balance: 6/10 (The difficulty levels vastly change in each stage, the crysis series is known for been abit die and restart)

Music: 8/10 (Good sound, never gets to loud or too quiet and everything sounds realstic and not self created)

Storyline: 8/10 (This is personal preference, but I enjoyed the storyline, you should be aware it's essential to play this game, crysis 2 in order to get the story for crysis 3

Overall: 8/10, Good game, worth buying, good storyline and combat mechanics, fun to run around killing AI with trucks and military vehicle guns and so on, Replayability is 0/10 because the storyline is 80% of the sticking point, it's almost impossible to play again and enjoy unless you're trying to achieve a personal goal with a different difficulty.

reviewText:
***Written in a nostalgic saturday night***


I started playing it when I was 13 years old, back in March 2008, I had to buy a new graphics card for my computer, an nVidia 9600GT, to be able to run the game with almost everything at minimum. And well, that breathtaking HALO jump intro hooked me into an incredible game with features that I hadn't experienced before. My mind was completely blown with this game. I played hours and hours and I enjoyed it so much, too bad my parents wouldn't let me play as much I wanted :(

**tears running down my face**

I even enjoyed with the most simple things I could do in this game, like picking up a cute turtle or a chicken, and throw it hundreds of meters away. Or hiting those tropical buildings smashing them into pieces, or driving like a crazy driver, or having a swim on a paradise beach while the sun was setting and some northkoreans were yelling strange things...


**maximum nostalgia**


Now, time for my subjective and totally parcial review. I can only give this game a 10/10 because what it meant at that time:

-no one ever had done a similar gameplay concept before
-the graphics were very advanced, and even today looks really nice
-The crytek engine, it was mind-blowing. At that time, who could ever think that it would possible to have so much freedom in a game? that it would be possible to pick up random animals and throw them away or even use them as weapons?
-The multiplayer, it put very well all that freedom into an online gameplay with a fair amount of players and very big maps
-To sum up, it became a reference in no time after release. Everyone would use it as a reference when comparing graphics , when building a new PC, when comparing gameplay features.... And the famous words NASA computer" became one of the most used for years thanks to this game.

Can the NASA computers run it today with all settings at max? :P"

reviewText:
I am somehwat twisted in regards to this game after having picked it up in the most recent sale.

First things first it has a lot of flat out amazing components. Right now I feel like Crysis graphics are in a sweet spot since they are, ahead of their time as they were 8 years ago still great but, finally achievable on midrange computers like mione. FYI I played on a an overclocked intel pentium g3258 and an r9 280 and fas more than pleased with the results. The gunplay and gameplay generally are definitely top notch. One of the strongest points of the game is, the way it appears to me, that it offers a surprisingly high amount of replayability with different approaches, such as relying more on stealth, sniping or throwing. This wide range of possibilities in game coupled with a lot of destroyability makes up for an shooter that even after some years is unsurpassed in certain regards. The story may at times appear incohesive  but is most definitely one of epic scale.

Despite all that i was for a moment on the verge of not recommending Crysis for pretty much just one reason. Bugs and glitches. During the last mission it occured to me not once not twice but over 20 times that I glitched through the floor to either die or get stuck. Afterwards I also crashed various times which allegedly madddened me a good bit more than I care to admit here. Those are however experiences that may have been individual to me. It may be, that you get to play this title without anything of that kind happening to you even once, leaving you with a 10/10 title.

reviewText:
I am not a big FPS fan because of how ♥♥♥♥ I am at them, but I like an FPS with an interesting hook. Crysis' nanosuit is that hook. It essentially allows you to play as you want and tailor your own experience. I played the entirety of the game using stealth and slow methodical tactics, whereas others played guns blazing, as a cover shooter. It is a sandbox in more ways than one.

In addition to that, the story is interesting and there are a few cinematic moments that get your adrenaline pumping

Needless to say that the game still looks amazing even after 6-7 years.

reviewText:
This game kinda sucks. I know its old, and for its time the graphics were amazing, but I just cant get over some pifalls of the gameplay. I know reviewing a game past its prime, you have to take things in consideration, but somethings I cant get over.

First thing you want to do is bind the suit powers to a certain key. You cant do this. Why?  Honestly, thats why this game gets a bad review. Im sure there might be a mod that I could download but im not wasting my time. Using the toggle suit powers doesnt work, and having to use the wheel toggle to flip back and forth is slow, I feel defeats the purpose of the suit.
You cant melee guys that dont see you for an instant kill.  Some cue appears to grab enemy but I could never get it to work properly. I have this badass suit but no knife? Really?
The AI is horrible. I play games on hard and ultra hard, and I hate games where you are forced to use glitches to kill guys on ultra hard. Half the time they dont see you when they clearly should, and other times they see you immediately when they shouldnt.  And that sucks because the game relys heavily on stealth.  I dont quite see the purpose of the silencer.  If you kill a guy with a silencer everyone hears it. Using the Speed Power boost doesnt frighten or stagger the enemies at all, which I find really dumb. If I zip past 2 guys you would think their would be some delay before they would just turn around and kill me. Nope.
Pick up another pistol, and youll duel weild automatically and lose the iron sights on the pistol.  I never figured out how to single wield, and you cant aim with pistol anymore.  Dont pick up another pistol, and youll have no pistol ammo.

Whats the biggest dissappointment is that you would think with the suit powers there would be some sort of combos or different play styles. There isnt. Strength is for jumping and breaking walls, speed is for getting around the map, armor is used for combat, stealth is what your forced to be in most of the time.

I just found it kind of lame because of these problems.  The story seems really good though.

reviewText: Crysis. From the company that had intrigued me for the longest time with their super realistic physics and graphics engine. I didn’t expect much from this game since the trailers made it look pretty much just like a tech demo. Surprisingly, though, it turned out to be a blast! Or at least half of it. There’s this supernatural atmosphere breathing down the neck of the player throughout the first act and it finally resolves itself as an alien invasion plot. Sadly, killing those aliens is just boring as hell. I would still classify this game as “good” because the first half of it is just so much fun. I must’ve spent hours just sneaking around the enemy bases and then tactically taking out the enemy soldiers from the shadows and that’s what made me wanna go on further and further. The graphics and physics are amazing and some of the driving and flying sections are a fun change of pace. It’s just that if we got a game that was like the first act of this game all the way through, it would easily deserve a couple of ranks higher score in my opinion.

reviewText:
Crysis is a first-person shooter game developed by Crytek and published by Electronic Arts in 2007.

An elite group travels to North Korea to investigate an artifact. While the player faces Korean soldiers and research facilities , an alien ship prepares to emerge and begin the invasion of Earth . Nomad faces Korean forces and tries to defeat the alien threat . The game submerges us under incredibly detailed rainforests. The physics of the game is excellent . Apart from the story, one enjoys walking around the environment , breaking the palms, catching animals, piloting boats , swimming with fish , and driving around the islands.

The graphics engine is the successor to Far Cry . It was a real revolution in real-time graphics . The image quality and texture is still among the best of all time . This makes the game very immersive . It took five years after release to play the game with very high quality settings and get a reasonable experience. Many people spoke at the time of bad optimization when in fact the game has three times more polygons than his contemporaries , volumetric clouds , day- night phases and huge maps. Nothing compared to the fixed pixelated sky on a Call of Duty game .

The player has a special suit that gives different powers or abilities for a period of time, such as invisibility , speed or armor. While it is not a Sandbox, it has open maps that simulate the world much better than its very linear successor, Crysis 2. In that regard, it is even better than Crysis 3.

The game was one of the best action games of 2007 but did not have many sales due to high specifications, hardware requirements and DirectX 10. It has two Secuels . Crysis 2 and Crysis 3 .
While Crysis 3 surpasses some of its graphic , 1 remains the best game of the 3 .

The game was released for Windows PC , PS3 and XBOX 360 before being ported to MAC OSX.

reviewText:
While Crysis' story was never really anything special to begin with, it certainly gets the job done. It takes some unexpected twists and turns along the way, and it does lead to a fairly interesting conclusion, but all in all it's clear that this is a game of gameplay over story. If you want something with a story that will rival franchises like Half-Life or Bioshock, you're looking in the wrong place. The story of all the Crysis games combined serves only one purpose, and that purpose is to give you a reason for going from A to B if wanderlust alone isn't going to cut it.

Now then, how is the gameplay?

The gameplay is great. It's everything you expect in a modern shooter - Decent-to-good AI, a nice selection of satisfying weaponry, explosives and gadgets. The Nano-Suit turns out to be one of the most interesting features in any FPS since the Gravity Gun, and the game is ripe for multiple playthroughs thanks to all of your options and the, at times, huge maps that you can get lost in. Crysis is perhaps the flagship of what a liniear open-world game can be - No, you're never really 'free' but you don't feel like you're being pushed through a bottleneck - because you're not! What Crysis likes to do is to give you a fairly simply objective, a huge map, and then basically leave it up to you as to how you go about completing your mission. You can go in guns blazing, blowing up enemies left, right and center, or you can play it like you would any stealth game, capitalizing on your ability to turn invisible.

Graphically there's not really much to say. You can pick up and play this game today, and you won't be disappointed. Even by our current standards, this game arguably looks better than a lot of new releases. The low pricetag also means that it's going to outclass a lot of otherwise very competent indi-shooters.

Definitely an all-time classic for me, and in my opinion the best game in the series.

reviewText:
One of the best FPS games ever.

I first played Crysis a few years after it came out and to say the least was blown away by it.

The graphics are some of the best (for the time) I've ever seen in a FPS, the gameplay and combat are superb, there are few things more enjoyable in any game as being confronted with a village full of North Korean troops chosing your line of attack and picking them off one by one using stealth mode. I could do it for days.

I like games which seem relatistic in that they are set in a earth like world but have fantasy or sci-fi elements in them.  Like in Half-life you fight humans and Aliens which is perfect as just one or the other does become boring. COD for example.

All in all for me this game is second only to Half-Life and even beats it in some ways. The first Crysis game is easily the best the second and third have the feel of rushed COD style sequels about them but are still superb.

On the whole Crysis is one of the best games ever made and if you havnt played it then why the hell not?

9/10 Utterly effing Brilliant.

reviewText:
After years of waiting to give this title a try, the opportunity finally presented itself and I carved out some time to really get into it.  Unfortunately, although it is a decent and mildly enjoyable game, I can't personally recommend Crysis.

What I had thought would be a unique experience turned out to be a run-of-the-mill, fairly generic First-Person Shooter that failed to draw me in.  The suit mechanics are the game's strong point, as they are entertaining to use, but the rest of the game is quite lackluster in comparison.  As I played, it seemed to me that what got this game its hype was, by and large, the advanced graphical features of its day.  On this end, I will say that the game still holds up even eight years later.  The game looked good and the animations were smooth.

As I stated previously, this is not a bad game, just one that no longer stands out for anything in particular.  If you're a huge fan of First-Person Shooters and need another to hold you over to the next release, I'd say go ahead and get it.  If you're looking for a new experience that's going to keep you enthralled for the length of the game, I would look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Ugh, this game is...annoying.

It still looks gorgeous. It has that going for it. The FPS is nice enough.

But the technical issues..first, it'll probably not even start to work on Win7. There's patches, but they hardly work. The Steam version doesn't even include the 64-bit version.

If you do get it running, it'l still probably crash and exit every so often. And now it's freezing my entire PC and causing a restart. I figured this was my PC - GPU stress test benchmarks cause absolutely no issues. It's just Crysis, every so often. After 10 scary sounding full PC crashes (and 30+ crash to desktop before), I gave up and looked up the ending online. It's boring.

If you're sure your hardware can handle it, it's fine. It's beautiful, the gameplay is challenging and mostly pretty good..but there's a bunch of 'eh' moments which really ruined it. A lot of the same, mixed with a broken game.

reviewText:
I don't see what makes this so great. Imagine Half-Life 2 except with terrible writing, crap weapons and a clumsy radial UI. Activating powers is a clunky affair and really difficult to do when enemies are crawling all over you. It's almost as if it was designed for a console controller instead of a keyboard and mouse, which is weird considering it was originally PC exclusive. You'd think you could be stealthy with the cloaking ability but as soon as you fire a weapon enemies instantly know exactly where you are from a kilometer away. Cons: Derivative and brainless. Poor writing.

reviewText: Instead of Crysis, it should be called Crashes, because that's what it does. The game literally crashed or froze on me 6 times during installation and in the menus, before I even got to the game itself. If I make any changes in the menu at all, it immediately crashes. I mean, I changed the suit voice from male to female and the game crashed. Changed from windowed to full screen...crash. Changed resolution...crash. ANY change will cause the game to crash. Not only that, there's a checkpoint system, a relic from consoles, that causes the game to freeze for 5 seconds every time you hit one of those checkpoints. So far I've hit one of those checkpoints about once every 3 minutes.\n\nI, therefore, cannot recommend this broken game and I can't believe it's being sold for money. I can't ever see myself finishing this game with all these crashes and freezes. It just ruins the experience.

reviewText:
This game puts me in an awkward spot as a PC gamer. On one hand, this game - back in 2007 - showed the superior power of PC processing power. On the other hand; good luck trying to run the game on a modern PC. The sad thing that I encoutered with this game was the fact that I had an easier time play this game on my xbox 360, then I had on my PC, that was made in 2014. This was due to the game seeming inability to run on a modern operating system, without the help of a user made patch for the game. Though at best the patch only seemed to be a tempory fix to the problem, and for seemingly no reason; I would have to download the patch again before I could get the game to work again. Eventually I just gave up on the game, and unistalled it from my library, which was a damn shame too, since for the most part the gameplay was pretty good. I Thought that it was better than it's sequels, at least until the aliens showed, and unruined any need for stealth in the game, and don't get me started on that damnable helicopter flying sequence near the end.

All in All, if you can get the game to run with no fus, then I can tell you at least that you are in for a mostly good game. Otherwise scan over information, in discussions, or ask if your systems OS can even come close to running the game before purchasing it.

reviewText:
I have never been so angered by a video game.

Crysis is a beautiful game. That's no secret. Beyond that, the shooting is competent and the nano suit adds a nice flavor to the game. It would be a pretty fun game if not for its glaring flaws. So let's dive into those.

The game is poorly optimized. It looks great, but similarly good looking games run better. I'm using a 4770k @ 4.6 GHz and an overclocked GTX 970. It runs very well on max with 4x AA in most situations, but it occasionally lags, especially against aliens with their numerous projectile effects.

Crysis can't seem to pick a difficulty and stick with it. You'll go fifteen minutes of easy gameplay, and suddenly it's impossibly difficult. The autosaves are few and far between, so you'll need to stay on top of that yourself. Assuming you don't die in a particularly difficult situation, you might die to any of the numerous bugs.

That's right. The game is HORRIBLY buggy. Here is a nice list of terrible deaths and game-breaking bugs I encountered on a single playthrough:
- Bumped into an object that is subject to phsysics. It collided funny and I was instantly killed by it, from full health, with 100% on armor.
- Randomly fell over dead on numerous occasions, no enemies nearby, full health, no mines.
- Vehicle bumps something at an odd angle, explodes.
- Clipped through a floor and into a fire.
- The second-to-last mission finished and crashed the game. Again. And again. I had to use a command console code to advance to the final mission.
- The final mission allows you to progress beyond something that is necessary to finish it, causing you to have to restart the mission.

The list could go on. I'm sure there are plenty I even forgot.

Beyond the bugs, the game itself is just frustrating. The ground shooting segments are usually good, but the vehicle segments are some of the worst I've ever played. The VTOL is unresponsive and clunky, made even worse by tornados that just throw you to the ground. The tank mission is entirely too difficult at times. There is an escort mission where your friendly has to keep warm, and he twice failed to keep up with me and stand near a fire, getting himself killed.

There is a lot of good in this game, but there are a lot of things so poorly executed, it clearly overshadows the good. Unless you're a masochist, do not buy this game.

reviewText:
Pros
+Great graphics
+Love the gun customization
+alien enemy is pretty cool.

Cons
-Aiming, even with a controller is godawful
-Driving, especially the tank level, is horrific
-Were some parts where objectives are too vague for my personal taste.
-A.I is a sniping ninja and will pull of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t kills from too far away making the game extremely annoying.
-randomly dying because of random Michael Bay explosions for no reason
-Ending is complete B.S., even though I know there are 2 sequels, the ending just feels like sequel bait for no reason.
-Main character is completely boring, no character development at all, even for an FPS, this is intolerable.
-Barely fun at times and when it does get fun, the fun parts are whisked away for less fun parts
-SPOILER ALERT: THE ALIENS ARE BARELY IN THE F****** GAME!!!!


Okay, so after completing the game, I know can give my full review on it, it's awful. And that's what pisses me off, because they got a lot of things right, but for everything they got right, they get 14 other things wrong.  First of all aiming is atrocious and I play with a controller, second driving is godawful and I hate the part where they FORCE YOU TO DRIVE A TANK WHILE THE A.I SNIPES YOU WITH F****** ROCKET LAUNCHERS!  Also the characters are so bland I probably won't remember their names after writing this review. The story is decent at times but there are huge plot holes in that too which I will list at the end. Also the difficulty is ridiculous, especially the final boss, who is only difficult because of random a** Michael Bay level explosions that kill you in a second and have no warning whatsoever, also the alien freeze ray thing is B.S.

I had to look online to figure out how to get unstuck, there was no button prompt for that.  The game's ending is also atrocious after dealing with two godawful, no fun, and above all lazy boss fights and by lazy I mean bosses that look cool but are so boring and not fun that you wouldn't want to ever fight them again, the ending doesn't feel like an ending. To be fair I am aware of Crysis 2 and 3 but honestly you can give us a better ending than just the main character saying No we get back in the fight" drop ship door closes thee end. Also the final boss feels more like a middle boss because SPOILER ALERT: YOU SPEND NEARLY 2 -THIRDS OF THE GAME FIGHTING KOREANS IN A JUNGLE AND ABOUT THE LAST 3RD OF THE GAME FIGHTING THE ALIENS!!!

If I wanted to fight Korean soldiers with an assault rifle I'd just play COD like everybody else (I hate COD by the way)
date: I expected to be fighting aliens within the first 3-4 levels but wrong they don't come till the end. Granted the aliens are fun
recommended: the first few times you fight them
hoursPlayed: until you realize there are only 2 TYPES OF ALIENS IN THE ENTIRE GAME EXCLUDING 2 BOSSES!!!!\n\nAnd the only difference? One is big and flies above and rains needler-like blades on you from above and can take a lot of damage
voteText: the other? Smaller
helpfulPercent: shoots at you with smaller projectiles
votesHelpful: and bum-rushes you for quick stabs. BORING.\n\nEverything falls apart in the final act
votesTotal: the first level outside with the aliens is phenomenal it's one of the best levels I've played in a shooter in a while
votesFunny: I felt like I was in some Summer Blockbuster
commentsCount:
and I was excited to see where the rest of the game was going (I expected a solid 3 -4 hours of alien fighting) and then the aircraft carrier level takes a steaming turd on it.

SPOILER'S AHEAD PLOT GRIPES:

-The fact that your team leader Prophet learns how to hot-wire an alien gun to use against the aliens is never addressed.
-Generic evil Korean villain for half the game serves no purpose but to be filler for when aliens show up and is also sent off in a weak boss fight.
-Your character has the personality of a turnip

-Aliens don't show up till like the last 2-3 levels instead of midway through the game like one would think.
-Main character walks into nuclear powered aircraft carrier reactor core and lowers the rods and does not suffer from radiation poisoning or any sort of side effects because nanosuit.
-Your boss leaves the aircraft carrier because he knows the nuke will fail and heads back to the island to fight instead of helping stop them from destroying your entire fleet.
-Ending is not an ending

it's like they cut a much larger game in half.

reviewText:
I'm sure it's a great game, but I'd never know because it won't launch!

Do not buy, unless you plan to spend hours troubleshooting the problems it has launching, installing useless 3rd party software and platforms that are out of business now, having to manually download patches and executables from unknown publishers, and mess with your anti-virus settings, compatibility mode exceptions, and on and on and on.

And if you're like me, after trying every possible solution posted online, it still won't work!  For a 9 year old game the prevalence of these issues for so so many people is just absurd.

There are so many other great games out there, I'm through wasting time trying to get this one to launch, bye Crysis.

reviewText:
Full of crashes and performance issues even after trying multiple x64 patches and steps.

While I was able to get the game to run with the x64 patch, some levels suffered severe performance drops (lowest and max graphics were same fps) and the game still crashed.
Most notibly is the 2nd last boss on the ship which I can not pass because the game plays at 10 fps or lower at parts or just simple crashes. I tried for almost 2hrs too and I am finally giving up without finishing the game.

About the actual gameplay and story:
Honestly I liked where the story was going and I liked the gameplay. The graphics were insane for how old it is and inside the enemy cave was a spectacular experience!

If you can manage to finish the game without issues then you are lucky as for me I'll probably watch someone else's playthrough just to get an end to the story... :(

EDIT: Also it didn't recognise the playtime with the x64 patch.

reviewText:
One of my absolute PC favourites so far
The gameplay was better than it's sequels and it truely felt like a master peice of a game, and I can see how it became a sequel. There were a few bugs here and there but even compared to graphics in some games now-a-days it's pretty impressive I would give a warning to anyone using 64bit windows as if it doesn't work you will have to find the same solution that I did (search run crysis in 64 bit) anyway here are the pros and cons:

pros:
- Graphics & sounds are great
- Gameplay is hard but very satisfying to explore the world and abuse the armour abilities
- Armour abilities feel more used than in the other 2 crysis games (in my opinion)
- The story is good, and not too basic, it is something that is impossible, but feels as though it might be possible (hard to describe)
- World doesn't feel cramped like other shooters
- Gameplay style is all your choice: from tactical stealth to total devastating running and gunning (though would recommend easier difficulty for more running and gunning)

cons:
- as mentioned before, it is a risky purchase for 64 bit windows as a solution doesn't always work...
- Some parts can seem almost impossible to get past
- Final boss battle can glitch out, meaning you have to do the whole thing again
- 2 objects in the game have weird graphics glitches when you walk past them (might just be me)

I'm pretty sure that's it for my review, hope I've helped make a decision :) just be careful if you are purchasing this game from a 64 bit of windows, and if you are and at first it didn't work, I hope the solution works for you!

reviewText: The original Crysis was always special to me. The lush island setting, the amazing graphics at the time, the size of the levels, the way we can approach a mission in anyway we wanted and the way it made me feel like a Predator. I was the first game I installed when I bought my first gaming PC. Yes, the story was not great but the game was so much fun nonetheless. It's always entertaining to throw things at an enemy or throw enemies rather than use weapons. The main character is also still one of my favorites :)

reviewText:
The game is a bit bugged, and does crash towards the end of the game: its only downfall. The gameplay is awesome. I am not a big fan of FPS, but what really kept me enjoying it was the atmosphere, very realistic, then at the same time very futuristic.

I enjoyed it thoroughly and beat it. Not sure how many hours it took( I had to disable the steam overlay as it causes some bugs.), but it definately was awhile, pretty big game

For being 7 years old the graphics deliver and still tax a system. For the price you can get it nowadays I definately recommend it.  I guess it stood the test of time, just like Prophet...that son of a ♥♥♥♥♥! hahaha (inside crysis joke)

reviewText: What can I say about Crysis that has not been said?  Graphically it set the new standard when it was released... presenting lush tropical environments, photo realistic underwater visuals, etc etc.  There is no question that the eye candy is here.  However, the gameplay is also fantastic.  Environments are vast and open, and objectives can be tackled in a variety of ways.  AI is actually intelligent and will pull off some interesting flanking moves.  The story isn't exactly original, but its well executed.  Multiplayer is too complex making it somewhat less accessible, but worth the single player experience. A must purchase for every FPS fan.

reviewText: If you love first person shooters, I would highly recommend picking this up.  If you own this and haven’t finished it yet, finish it.  It’s not that long of a game.  If you’re not the greatest at FPS’s, but wouldn’t mind trying one out, plop Crysis on easy and have a go.  I feel you won't be disappointed unless you’re expecting a deep and twisting plot line, in which case, you’re looking in the wrong place.  That’s just fine with me and my science fiction shooters.\n\nThe game looks, controls, and plays great. This is an oldie but a goodie and should be enjoyed by those with a desire to play an FPS that doesn't require you to jump online to have the most fun.

The game has some blatant optimization issues as it STILL chugs on my current system with 2 970s, 24 GB of ram and an FX 9370 AMD CPU but none the less it's still pretty fun and has an interesting story for a first play through

reviewText: Yes, this game has amazing graphics (just getting it out of the way). The combat is smooth and very complex, thanks to the ubiquitous nano-suit, which can help you run at superhuman speeds, punch through walls (or kill enemies with one blow from a toilet brush), or turn invisible for a short period of time. The settings vary considerably, from the almost-tropical beaches to the icy mountains of the Lingshan Islands. Weapon selection was good, and only improved when the Aliens were unleashed (Molecular Accelerator or Gauss Rifle, anyone?). It should also be pointed out that the plot shift from focus on North Korea to the Alien threat was a pleasant surprise, as it changed things up before they became too boring. The story was not that great, and the characters rather pathetic in their own right (save for Psycho), but hey! When the action is this good, who's complaining? Great weapons customization options (each weapon can be tailored to the individual players' needs). The vehicular combat was not spectacular, but another game made by Crytek down the line will address that...\n9/10

reviewText:
4/5

A fun FPS with a twist. You play as a futuristic Super-soldier with the ability to turn invisible or turn your Armor on to resist bullets.

This game is semi-open world and gives you the option for multiple ways to take down your enemies. The combat is fun and engaging, and definitely keeps you on your toes. You can only carry a handful of weapons at a time, you constantly need to monitor your suit's energy usage, and you never know when there's a hidden sniper waiting in a tree for you.

The game allows you to roll with your own playstyle if you prefer to run in with Armor and a shotgun or stealth through the bushes with a long range rifle. The weapons are all responsive and unique, and customizable to suit yourself. I found myself struggling to decide which ones I wanted to keep with me.

The environment is beautiful, the entire island is rich and looks like they put a lot of effort into it. The areas where you make enemy contact are designed for fun firefights with lots of movement and interaction with the environment--especially when some of it is destructible.

However, the game is a bit repetitive and there are only like 2 boss fights, so a lot of your time is spent running around the island and dealing with more normal enemies, with a few breaks in the monotony. Also about 2/3 of the way through the game, the focus is shifted more towards fighting aliens instead of the human enemies, which changes the gameplay a little bit.

Still, it was a fun adventure, a good FPS, and interesting story.

reviewText:
Crysis is this game.
Crysis Warhead is a psuedo sequel, the same time frame played from your buddy's perspective.
Crysis Wars is defunct multiplayer.
Crysis 2 is the proper sequel but plays very differently than the above.
Crysis 3 (and 4) are on Origin" not Steam.

Background:
Crysis was the benchmark in PC graphics for a very long time.  It's 2016 and this game still looks fairly decent.  Probably the first game I've ever played where a forest feels like a real forest.  Way ahead of its time and most people's hardware.  Unfortunately it also missed out on a lot of optimization potential that later games got right.  Even with a GTX 970 with comparable SSD+processor this game loads slowly and did have issues in an aerial sequence.  I had settings almost maxed (keep that motion blur disabled thanks) except for the aerial bit.  The UI is terrible and every session I had to put fullscreen back on.

Gameplay:
This is an oldschool first person military shooter with sandbox elements and regular cut scenes.  You start off with all suit powers (hold middle click and drag in a direction):
- default is armor which includes faster health regen
- then cloak is overpowered (drains power as you move and drops if you attack) yet fails at melee range.
- strength makes you jump higher and absorb more falling damage
- speed makes you run faster
date:
really fast for a short time

Good to know stuff:
Falling damage can kill (use strength to minimize).  The suit lets you breath underwater.  There's also a separate night vision that drains a separate power meter.  Armored vehicles require explosives to destroy.  You can only carry three kinds of weapons at a time
recommended: but can swap on the fly and recall a previous weapon's ammo pool (which is the only reason to swap late game).  Health is regenerative but the meter is on screen.  In this iteration
hoursPlayed: ammo pickups are totally manual.  Crouch and fully prone are separate functions.  WHENEVER YOU GET IN A VEHICLE HIT F1 FOR THIRD PERSON!  No achievements or collectibles
voteText:
just secondary objectives with no impact aside from providing another ammo cache.  Relatively short compared to today's titles (9-15 hours).

Verdict:
Crysis was a great game in its time.  It's an oldschool precursor to the Call of Duty franchise.  But if that's what you're hoping for
helpfulPercent: you won't enjoy this.  The game is fairly unforgiving (though stealth is an obvious option) and there are a few really annoying aspects.  Ammo
votesHelpful: enemy
votesTotal: and suit power management are a must.  Play on easy if you are at all worried
votesFunny:
you will still die a bunch.  It's polished but not streamlined; if you played any of the other games (which included many quality of play improvements) you might want to skip this one.

Psuedo spoilers "what are you getting into":
The game has several innovative sequences
commentsCount: but that could also be a source of frustration as the game starts off almost sandbox then gets fairly linear.  The game shifts in tone and even play style half way through
column16: leading me to miss the earlier sections of assaulting Korean bases.  The ending absolutely has a nice final boss for a climax
column17: but then acts like one of the next games will pick up your character's life a few minutes later.  They don't
column18: making that sort of a cliffhanger.\n\nBottom line:  Worth $4"

reviewText: Crysis got a bad wrap because of the insane gaming rig necessary to play, but if you had a computer that could run it, Crysis was one of the best in the genre. The visuals were, obviously, stellar, but it was much more than that. Over time, the gameplay became… customizable. You could stealth in the middle of a group of enemies, grab one by the throat, throw him, drop a trip-mine, and run away before they even knew you were there. You were Batman mixed with the Predator mixed with The Flash, and it was freaking incredible. The expansion, Crysis: Warhead, turned down the plot and turned up the over-the-top gameplay, so, you know, it was also awesome.

reviewText:
To preface this, I am not fully finished with this game but  i have a good amount of hours into the story. I bought it on steam and due to some odd glitches i've had to fenagle my way into playing it. Onto my review.


I've played crysis 2, and maybe that was bad before playing this first. I'm fairly into the game at the momentand feel that it's increasingly repetitive and overall a bit lacking. Stealth mechanics are bare to where you would think the Koreans all wore some sort of extra-sensory devices. Hiding behind anything, inside bushes...doesn't work. If you get seen, prepare to fight hands on for the ENTIRE chapter. Every enemy will know where you are and there's no way to reduce the aggro enough to go back to stealth mechanics. Perhaps I'm overdoing the stealth, or just suck, but that's my opinion on that.

The story so far is not completely amazing, but it's building slowly but surely. I wish I cared more about the faceless nanosuit owners who fight with you (for the first minute or so of each chapter, then you're a lone wolf).

As for running the game....it's not bad for me personally.  I have an 800$ pre-made laptop and can run it on high" until the action kicks up. after the sixth or so enemy starts blasting you
date: the frame rate drops a bit.\n\nNot a bad game
recommended: buy it if you're bored and it's on sale. I did.  6/10\n"

reviewText: It is sad to say that I cannot recommend the Steam version of the game as for some reason it does not run for me no matter what  I've tried to fix the game. If you really want to play the game I would highly recommend getting the original DVD of the game and install it from there. (that's what worked for me at least)\n\nAs for Crysis itself, it is an absolutely beautiful game. The freedom of choice of approach to your objectives is unlike any other game even to this day. Unlike the Crysis 2 or 3 which just gives you 3 or 4 different approaches, it is completely up to you in the original Crysis. The beautiful graphics and the design of the jungle in the game that still challanges the hardware of today is like a cherry on top making it the best game of 2007 and one of the best games to this date.

reviewText: At its best, Crysis is an immersive free roam FPS with a few cool abilities that you can use in battle. At its worst , Crysis is a boring repetitive FPS with a bad story and nothing interesting to explore. Crysis has a mediocre unbalanced multiplayer, a campaign that's no fun, and an irritating AI. The graphics are good and the sound effects are awesome but those two things don't really make up for the arguably bad gameplay and the repetitive missions.\n

reviewText:
One of the most overrated FPS games I have ever played.

I started playing this game at about 4pm

I finished it at 10:30PM.

It is woefully short...

The AI is stupid, the game becomes repetitive, the characters suck. The plot at times has twists that are just silly. It is as if an 8th grader wrote this thing.

The graphics are stunning I will give it that, but it ends up being exactly like a convertable with a 60 year old engine under the hood. Looking nice out on the outside but runs crappy when you use it.

Spend your money elsewhere

reviewText: Yet another “ohhh, that’s purdy” game from the makers of Farcry…except it’s not as pretty as RAGE and it’s not as inspired as Farcry 2. It’s sad, really, because now we’re getting ready to have Crysis 3, but I just don’t see it. Maybe I haven’t played enough into the game…I don’t know. I’m lost on what the selling point of these actually are besides the graphics.  And I’m not saying good graphics = bad game, either.\n\nAll I’m saying is I really don’t see anything in this game other than another boneheaded FPS that appeals to the lowest common denominator. I certainly won’t (and can’t) stop you if that’s your thing, but I feel very meh about this one.

reviewText: I don't recommend this game unless you really want to experience the story or gameplay of Crysis. I thought it was a mediocre game that is somewhat hyped. It came out 2007 but I just played it in Jan 2014 so maybe that is way I'm not so impressed w/ the gameplay or graphics. I did like one of the levels though and do appreciate some of the mechanics although what really killed the game were all the crashes. This game crashed so many times it became unbearable to the point where I was about to quit. Luckily I held on and finished it but I wouldn't recommend it for anyone one else. Like I said, okay game w/ okay story plus game crashing bugs equals not worth it for me. Unless of course if you really, really want to.\n

reviewText:
Glorified tech demo. Terrible AI, cliche plot and characters (including a random british bloke), and frustrating gameplay mainly because of the AI.

Whilst the game looks graphically amazing, its a chore to have to play. Enemy helicopters just endlessly following you no matter what, soldiers that spot you immediately and somehow hivemind with the rest of the soldiers your exact position, so that guy on a mounted gun miles away begins shooting at you precisely. The game isn't difficult though, it's just dumb. The suit functions are a nice idea, but hardly add to gameplay whatsoever combined with their limited on use time.

My rating is 58, all just for the quality of graphics.

reviewText: Whilst it received critical acclaim, Crysis is but perhaps the most generic first-person shooter to land on the PC platform.  The story is all but engaging and at times predictable and cheesy as it is.  It's a typical Hoorah" game that puts you in command of a nano-engineered super suit that greatly enhances the human body to the extremes of superman-like abilities.  While the game surely has some memorable moment they don't justify the poor A.I with nearly pinpoint accuracy
date: graphical glitches and a forgettable story.\n\nIf anything
recommended: Crysis is - or was - only meant to stress hardware and see just what your system is capable of

reviewText:
This game has not aged well. The graphics that once looked so lifelike look like they were pasted on to give the illusion of looking lifelike. Grab an enemy and look at his face, you can see where the video file was essentially pasted onto the characters face. Their actual movement animations look pretty bad now. The water still looks absoutely gorgeous though, and the game's graphics do have their moments still. But don't expect your brand new 2013 super computer to be able to run this 2007 monster any better. You'll still get some pretty poor performance as soon as you hit that snow part.

The gameplay itself was never that great. A very small arsenal of weapons to choose from, made only smaller due to the fact that the enemies only use AK's, Uzis, and Shotguns so you'll be stuck using their guns since there's rarely any way to replenish the other weapons in the game like the Scar. And once you get to the part with the aliens.. forget it. The gameplay is terrible. Bad hit registration, barely having any indication of how much damage you're doing to enemies, repetition. The end fight is pretty epic, but this game still comes off as just an advertisement for Cryteks graphics engine in 2007.

Honestly, Crysis 2 and Crysis 3 have better gameplay because they're more finely focused on it rather than putting all their eggs in the graphics basket.
voteText: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The concept and the world design are beautifully executed, but not much else. Gameplay, AI, story, all pretty boring. Not enough save points. Sometimes stupid bugs you can't control destroy all your progress and you have to start back at some checkpoint you reached 30 minutes and 500 dead enemies ago.

I finished it without too much trouble, but it felt like a chore. The gameplay does not have much depth; it's mostly just 'stay alive and shoot the baddies to death.' It is hard to feel satisfied by the combat or to get immersed in it.

Get Crysis 2. You won't be missing much if you don't get Crysis 1.

reviewText:
2 hours in and I think I will shelve this game.

The targeting is off.  Enemy AI seems to be able to see through cover, and in the beginning of the game they put you in an abandoned town and tell you to kill 2 tanks.  3 rockets, 5 grenades, and several shotgun blasts through the top of the tank later, I haven't downed one.

yaaaaaawn

The suit modes are cool, but the awkward transition between them in controller mode makes combo maneuvers difficult.  It's a little easier with the mouse.  Overall, the game didn't hook me within the first couple of hours, and i'm probably going to just shelve it.  There is no level up mechanic, or customization options so i have a feeling the gameplay is going to get stale by the end of the game anyway.

reviewText: Kind of a mixed bag is this one. Played it for the first time and after playing Crysis 2 i must say they definitly made improvements from the original. For starters the game looks great. You can immediatly tell why this was a PC Breaking game back in 2011. Graphics with water, fog, and lighting are amazing to look at and the environments are varied and exciting. Gameplay is where is seems to be the jumble of good and bad. The combat is tight and responds well however the driving is crap and the flight missions downright stupid. The waypoints system works at times but in others i found myself running around looking for the right path to take in the later levels. sometimes there was absolutly no direction unless I opened my objectives tab and read the fine print. NOW we hit the big problem with this game. The difficulty spikes are incredibly crushing to the point of infuriation. Cheap ♥♥♥ deaths from instant killing enemies that you cant see are increasingly frustrating especially when you have the suits armor on and at full health. WTF Crytek. give us the tools but they dont help with them at all? Disappointingly frustating difficullty in an otherwise pretty and competant shooter. Would reccomend to crysis fans for the story and length only. You could spend money on 2 and get a better product. Die hard fans would enjoy but for me I wont be reentering the first game any time soon.

reviewText:
Crysis' graphics could put even many newer games to shame.

Pros: Graphics, Sound, Gameplay
Cons: Story, Controls, Multiplayer, Bugs

From the reflections in the rippling water to the slow-moving fog that crawls atop the jungle, Crysis' graphics are not only incredible but easily enjoyed on high to very high on most new computers.  The music and sound is equally impressive, with 5.1 surround sound.  Crysis offers many refreshing ways of tackling its missions in the first half.

However, the story gives little time to interact with any other characters, let alone care for them.  An abrupt twist in both the plot and gameplay leaves more to be desired.  The controls are good in many ways, but clunky in many others, for example, toggle aim but no hold-down, hold-down sprint but no toggle.  Unfortunately, multiplayer has been shut down and a number of bugs will never be patched.

Lacking both story and multiplayer, Crysis offers very little that newer shooters can't.

7/10

reviewText:
This is a good game considering its release date but a play through these days reveals it's age. Definitely worth a trip through if you have never played it before but there are better FPS games from this era out there. 7/10

Pros
+ graphics are good considering its age
+ the suit mods were pretty innovative for the games era
+ weapons are realistic and fairly varied
+ vehicles are a neat addition

Cons
- storyline is weak
- gameplay is very linear
- switching between suit mods is cumbersome
- I wasn't crazy about the zero-grav level (though I'm probably in the minority)
- HMGs are pretty underpowered
