reviewText: I remember the times of old when Crysis was used to benchmark everything. It's a game I fondly remember for it's brillant and fun gameplay with gorgeous visuals that put modern games to shame but it's far from perfect.\n\nGraphically, it was easily the most taxing game when it came out. Can it run Crysis on max?" was a common way to judge a computer's performance
recommended: it's a intense game to run. Although released in 2007
hoursPlayed: it still looks gorgeous. The Lingshan Islands feel like very realistic in it's scope and detail. Texture quality rivals
voteText: if not outright better than
helpfulPercent: modern textures
votesHelpful: and lighting effects are done to perfect. All in all
votesTotal: it's visually stunning. Worthy to note is the interactivity of objects in the game. The ability to shoot at enemies in cover and destroy their cover completely is realistic and not to mention being able to break most objects in game. Houses
votesFunny: fences
commentsCount: trees and cars are all destructable and this should be abused to the best of your abilities.\n\nGameplay wise
column16: it's a sandbox
column17: first person shooter
column18: and arguably the best of it's genre. Guns feel like they have a real kick to them and the shotgun especially feels immensely satifisying to use compared to modern first person shooters. The nanosuit has 4 but all very distinct and useful "modes". All 4 modes use energy
column20: to power their actions. Power mode allows for steadier aim
column21: stronger melee attacks and higher jumps[/spoiler]. Armor modes allows damage to be absorbed via energy. Speed mode allows for faster movement in every situation including walking
column23: running and even moving up ladders (not to mention a ridiculously fast sprint). Finally Cloak mode allows for limited invisibility. However
column24: being tied to a limit and ever draining resource
column25: there is an art to using the functions of the nanosuit. It's immensely satisfying to cloak into cover behind an enemy
column28: and then use speed mode to quickly sprint away into new cover. There's also a bit of depth into the mechanincs of the nanosuit
column29: and the game doesn't hold your hand into it. It never tells you to use power mode when you're trying to snipe at long distances
column30: or to use speed mode sprinting while swimming or in zero-g environments to move rapidly. Guns feature on-the-fly customisation
column31: and you can tailor each gun to each specific circumstance
column32: such as adding a silencer with a sniper scope on your assault rifle to act as a long range sniper
column33: or switch it up with a reflex scope and grenade launcher for drawn out firefights. There are a few vehicles to use including tanks
column34: military jeeps and even VTOLs but they're nothing really special apart from using jeeps in creative ways to kill KPA soldiers in the first half of the game.\n\nStorywise
column35: it's very barebones. You're sent to investigate an island who have american researchers taken hostage by the North Korean military (KPA or Korean People's Army). It then is revealed that an alien race is lying dormant with the KPA trying to use them as an limitless energy source. This backfires and instead wakes the aliens and the US military arrives to try and stop them before they contact their homeworld for reinforcements.\n\nThe few main characters are lively and full of character
column36: especially your squadmates of Raptor Team. Their voice actors do a terrific job putting so much personality into them
column37: including the voice actors for quite a lot of the characters you'll meet. Although there is an exception. Helena Rosenthal was done by Claudia Black
column38: responsible for Chloe in the Uncharted Series and Morrigan in the DA series. She does an okay job in those
column39: but she is absolutely awful in Crysis. Whenever Helena's voice comes on it's like a nails on a chalk board. Absolutely jarring and breaks your immersion. You really have to think how the production team okayed this
column40: when the other characters like Psycho or Prophet are done so well.\n\nHowever the game is ultimately flawed in many aspects that take away from the experience. The first half of the game is a brillant open world FPS that allows for creative ways to approach every objective. Abusing Cloak feels cheap
column41: but mastery is difficult to achieve resulting in a rather balanced experience. You can still end up in a terrible position with no energy to absorb hits if you don't position properly which means instant death at the higher difficulties. Enemies can also spot you while cloaked if you move in close proximity to them and even while remaining still if they're in touching range. Personally
column42: I play this like a Predator simulator
column43: and it's immensely satifisying to cloak in and out
column44: while headshotting soldiers undetected and causing an alert to go off while you continute to flank and pick soliders off one by one. Unfortunately once you reach the second half of the game
column45: it becomes a completely different game. After you reach the mines and the alien temple within
column46: it becomes a linear FPS with bullet sponge enemies (The aliens you'll fight
column47: the KPA nanosuit soliders aren't so bad). While this isn't bad on it's own
column48: you have to play a completely different style. You can't stealth kill (as in cloaking and headshotting) and so you are forced to shoot behind cover
column49: ducking to recover your armor. I wouldn't mind this in it's own game
column50: but to lose that sense of freedom and ability to play as you see fit from the first half
column51: is a real shame. The game also suffers from numerous bugs
column52: including odd physics interactions like a fallen tree shaking and walking into it causing instant death
column53: falling into the floor of the USS Constitution and getting stuck and the infamous bug where you crash upon trying to load a game (which you can fix by deleting the most recent save in your savegame folder).\n\nAll in all
column54: it's an immensely fun game to play with multiple ways to play it as you see fit. The visuals are gorgeous and constant screenshot worthy moments. Although there are a few bugs (some almost game breaking)
column55: the overall experience is worth to chug through them. I would advise to replay the first half after finishing the game though
column56: you'll see just how much more fun it was if you didn't notice it already."

reviewText:
For it's age Crysis is a very pretty game. Of course, the fact that it runs on the Crytek engine may have something to do with that, but even on lower spec machines it should still provide you with some nice eye candy. The game play is also quite good, with a variety of vehicles and weapons to choose from throughout the game.

Unfortunately, the prettiness and good game play doesn't make up for the somewhat short storyline in the single player game, easily completable in sixteen hours. That said, the storyline is engaging, if a little cliched in places.

On balance, this is a good game and definitely worth a look if it's on sale.

reviewText:
Crysis is a beautiful and rich game with great sound effects and music, but the bugs almost ruined the entire experience.

Most FPS games are a straight-forward affair; go here, shoot this, press this button, shoot that. Whilst Crysis doesn't complete escape a linear format, it does offer you secondary objectives and lets you tackle things from multiple angles. Fancy going in guns blazing? You can do that. Want to be sneaky and take out enemies silently or avoid them completely? Sure, go for it. The environments are varied so you never feel that you're just going through the motions, and adaptability is to key to survival.

Whichever way you play Crysis, it's a thoroughly enjoyable game and the great sound and music fit the moments perfectly, notching up the tension and then exploding into action if the preverbal hits the fan. Graphically, Crysis was well-known for bringing the best pixel-pushers to their knees, and even today, it looks mighty impressive. I played on 'high' and the texture quality, lighting and character animations look superb. I played through the story in 8 hours, which is standard fare for a game of this type.

Crysis does a lot of things very well, but all this is nearly destroyed toward the end of the game, as the final chapter is buggier than the Amazon rainforest. Falling through the ground to your death makes it incredibly frustrating and damn-near impossible to complete the game. When I made it to the final boss, the scripted-sequence failed and I had to reload a previous save, forcing me to do the battle all over again.

Edit: I was able to get around some of the clipping issues by forcing the game to run in DX9 mode, but this didn't always work. I had to jump and hope that I landed on solid ground.

Despite the bugs, I'd still recommend Crysis. It was thoroughly enjoyable and, final chapter aside, it's a highly polished game.

reviewText:
You should really play this game on Easy mode if you want to get a real experience of being a super soldier. Otherwise you'll end up rarely using Strength mode or Speed mode because you'll just get shot up trying to do, well, anything involving those traits. And on the harder difficulties all the enemy soldiers have got to be wearing several bulletproof vests each given the number of gutshots they can take without dying. In any case, outside of being menaced by helicopters and fighting aliens you never really have any trouble at all taking out enemy soldiers if you have good coordination with uncloaking, headshooting, then recloaking.

I understand some consider this game a pure exercise in video game graphics rendering and couldn't care less about the story but I honestly enjoyed it immensely.

Sidenote: Every year when it gets cold out I will reference the sequence where you had to escort Prophet from heat source to heat source because his suit malfunctioned. That part stuck with me for some reason.

reviewText:
MAXIMUM GAME [ wzzz... ] - literally.
First of all:
This is the game which although coming from the 2007's, but does not make any sense 'cos it's definitely worth every single bucks.

Let's face w/ the pro's & contras:

(+)	  You can prove your skills in a demanding, very extreme environment w/ such a realism.
(+)	  AI could be very difficult to beaten: no matter how much firepower you have. You have to
be proactive in the battlefield. You have to be flexible, quick & also think tactical.
(+) 	 The overall graphics (which is still standout nowadays) is more than eye-candy.
(+)	  Outstanding O.S.T. compositions (actually at the moment while I'm writing this review, I'm listening Inon Zur - Crysis    O.S.T. tracks).
I love it.
(+)	  The storyline scientific, exciting and bursts. That's what I'm talking about!
(+)	  Unique, unbeatable jungle & frozen world implementations. Goosebumps!
(+) 	 Technologically, optimized well. Runs w/ 40 - 50 fps on today's gaming rigs.

(-) 	 I have played this game in HARD difficulty level, which means - if you're dumb, AS I WAS in some cases - then you gonna die
at least 20x times at some poins. That can be annoying.
(-)	  Also, at some points, the game can be buggy, throwed me to desktop 4x times (at the last two chapters).
(-)	  Some platforms and quests are unlogically, unnecessary.
(-) 	 Sometimes the physics engine can act unrealistically.

So at the end of the day, this is a STILL ATTRACTIVE game, which is DEFINITELY recommended for folks, who simply luv' demanding shooters,
w/ scientific & exciting storyline.

Played on my Alienware 17 notebook @1600x900 resolution, with ultra high settings at avg. 40 - 60 fps.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Overall Crysis offers the player a good experience. However, if the player is looking for a smooth transition from beginning to end, they will fall a bit short. Game difficulty moves far too quickly from cakewalk to hell on Earth and back again too quick and far too often. Progressive difficulty is expected with any game. It naturally makes the game imersive so the player doesn't get bored. Finding levels later in game which seem nearly impossible only to move on to levels that are about as difficult as a tutorial is a bit much. Some levels you don't even have a damn clue what you're doing. For instance *spoiler alert!*...you end up in a different world a long time ago in a far away land. For some reason suddenly the gravity turns off. Ok...so I have thrusters. Didn't know that. Why the hell don't they help me jump higher along with the strength ability? Anyways...you'll find yourself inside this thing...we have no clue what it is. Some sort of factory? No clue. Enemies will be flying around you and giant bolts of electricity will be doing the funky chicken along the walls. So you try to figure out what you need to do. More and more bolts of electricity are forming and you start to wonder if the last 5 min you've spent in the area is all for nothing because you can't figure out what you're supposed to do. No...thats not it at all. Its a countdown to a portal that is going to whisk you away. So it turns out its a waiting game. Anyways, *end of spoiler!*

PROS:
-You get an awesome suit with different abilities which are not only fun to play with they are a must to complete missions.
-The learning curve is surprisingly fast.
-Good graphics. Honestly though even for its time...I don't see what all the fuss was about.
-It is one of the better single player FPS experiences out there.

CONS:
-3 main guns until right near the end. At which point you're so happy to pull the trigger of a new gun you nearly have an 0rg@smic moment which can only be bested by finding the 3rd warp whistle in Mario 3 when you're 12.
-On the later guns...(oh yes I'm not done!)...what is described as basically a nuke in a shotgun's body needs a Ph D and 20 yrs experience from Nasa JPL just to figure out how to work the damn thing and figuring out what to aim it at to make it work.
-*spolier alert* Aliens...not just regular aliens like E.T., Jarjar Binks, Predator, or Padme' Ama f'in dala (yes she was an alien...technically...a rather hot one at that,) these aliens are deadly flying around in Zero G. They are deadly (mostly 1 hit kills) on the ground. They blow up when dead. They pilot some serious hardware. Why the hell do they need all this? They can kill Billy King Badass in his super Badass suit with bare hands.
-3 weapons.
-Being invisible doesn't last as long as it should. In many ways it is nearly pointless. More invisible time=more fun.
-Multiplayer is dead.
-3  ♥♥♥1ng guns. RAWR!
-Hot research lady scenes do not contain a lap dance. =)

reviewText: This game looks incredible. It's beautiful to look at. There are segments that make you gasp at how good it looks. Other than that, the game is pretty good. The weapons are standard, the armor is fun to use, and the stealth is good. The controls are kind of dumb, like the fact that the ADS is a toggle, not a hold, and the level design is somewhat complicated and unintuitive. The story is good, and it balances stealthy covert operations, all-out warfare, and alien invasion very well. The vehicles are, however, complete garbage on wheels. They do no damage, are nearly impossible to see out of, and can take about ten shots before destruction. Overall, a good game, but the graphics are where you will get your money's worth.

reviewText: If you have the hardware to run this game, I would definitely recommend this game.  People say that the game was only made to show off the cry-engine, but I played this game on lowest settings on my old computer and still had a blast.  I recently re-played it on my new computer though on highest settings and it was still fun as hell.  People say that there are multiple ways to complete an objective.  but it basically boils down to sneaking through everything, the minute you turn off your cloak every enemy in a 2 mile radius instantly turn their guns toward your face and unloads every remaining clip they have into it.  you may have a Shield" but it seems like its made of paper mache and will break as soon as a single bullet hits you.  but in the end
date: it is still fun to cloak
hoursPlayed: uncloak and use strength mode to throw one of them into the air like a clay pigeon."

reviewText:
좆중딩때 컴퓨터 처음 바꾸고 제일 먼저 복돌로 돌린 게임이다. (예전컴이 카스온라인 정도 간신히 돌렸던 컴이라서 항상 크라에 대한 동경심이 엄청 났었을 때 )
막 중옵하옵 나올까봐 걱정했는데 상옵이 나오는 바람에 정말 감동받아서 울컥할정도로.. 감격했었다. 그런데 프레임 병신이라서 중옵으로 내린건 함정이지만.

벌써 5년전 이야기다. 복돌로 돌리고 질질싼고 5년만에 다시 정돌로 구입했다.
(아예 크라이시스 콜렉션을 사버렸지 ㄲㄲ)

다시 해보니 5년전 두근두근한 그 감격이 여전히 묻어나와서 정말 기쁘다.

그당시엔 전혀 몰랐는데 이 게임이 무려 메타스코어 91점이라더라.

그래서 더 재밌어진 것 같기도 하다. 타격감 병신이어도

reviewText: I really enjoy this game. It has great graphics and amazing gameplay. You are able to activite super strength, where you can jump very high and punch with high damage, speed mode, in which you go fast, cloak, which hides you from enemies, shield mode, which uses your energy as extra shields, and you can customize your weapons. You can add a silencer, different attachments, scopes and other things to your weapons. The game is very fun but challenging, the singleplayer is great, and the multiplayer is kind of empty and mostly boring. As long as you prefer single player games, I would highly recommend this game. It also has a great price.

reviewText: This was a FUN game. The multi-functional suits and the various gameplay elements combined well to create a wonderful experience that I kept returning to. Beaning koreans with chickens on Maximum Strength was a funny sideline, but I was very eager to see what the next mission and turn brought to the table. The plot twists are great, and it's fun how it ends up at the end. It's also a great example of the cutting edge technology and the intense push for better graphics that the Crysis engine embodied. I was glad to see what all the hype, and the 'will it run Crysis' meme was about.

reviewText:
FIX:
----------------------------------------------
1) Locate the Crysis Bin32 folder. (It should be in /steamapps/common.)
2) Rename the Bin32 folder to Bin32old.
3) Download the 64bit Launcher. http://www.mediafire.com/?wd5zwku0pj4tnni
4) Extract the files using winrar (or something).
5) Inside, there is a new Bin32 folder. Place in the same location as Bin32old.
6) Install any DirectX updates.
7) BAM! Game works.

reviewText: This game is a lot of fun until you have to fight the aliens =o. Great story line and some cool characters. But most of all, some really nice mechanics and AI that allow you to play however you want. Most of the game does not seem insanely linear, in that you can choose many different paths to the objective. Also when your fighting the humans; because of the AI and mechanics, you can go through the level without killing anyone if you want to. So i would highly recommend this game for those stealthy sniper types. The only complaints i have about this game are: some of the alien fights are a bit scripted and maybe just a tad to hard to pull off right away but there aren't many of them, the steam version didn't come with 64 bit...but a few extra steps will get that running, and my last complaint is the game feels pretty short and ends right when you feel motivated to kick some alien ♥♥♥.

reviewText: It would have been nice if it were made more clear that the game apparently doesn't work on 64-bit operating systems. I now see that Windows 7 isn't even listed in the supported OS list, and a message about only 32-bit systems is sneakily tucked away in an asterisk line, but this is a very rare thing considering the game is only a few years old, and the fact that a huge chunk of users can't play this game should be made more clear to potential buyers. I've been duped, fair enough, but I just wanted to help spread the word so others don't make my same mistake.\n\nAgain, if you have a 64-bit system, don't buy, doesn't work.

reviewText:
Crysis, a PC ball-busting, epic, sci-fi, fps where your a bad-♥♥♥ super soldier nomad.
The engine for this game is different, and imo better than the sequel's engine. The gameply feels more polished, more origional and just more entertaining, nothing quite makes me laugh more than holding terrified north koreans soldiers by the throat and lobbing them into the air.
Everything about this shouts sleek inovation and crytek made their name bigger and better because of this title.

Play this before any other crysis and you will understand why its the motherload.

Crysis = still the best.
Crysis Warhead
Crysis 2
Crysis 3

This game is a must buy, dont be intimidated by the reputation of its pc crushing capabilities, current standard pcs can play this on high settings (usually).
My pc is fairly old now, a 2007 quad-core 4gb dell model, my graphics card is a 1gb geforce 440, handled it fine.

reviewText:
It's a good FPS game, and a solid storyline.

The Joke 'But can it run Crysis' may not be meaningful, but the game still looks very good for it's age.  Controlling well with KB&M, and overall very entertaining.

The Difficulty modes barely do anything to the difficulty and mean almost nothing, except change if you can understand the enemy or not, & a slight boost to AI, NPC damage/resistance.  Worth playing on hardest difficulty for the fun of it, so you're not bothered by their chatter in English.

Easily finished & worth while for the storyline alone.  There is a few difficulty jumps, but nothing that isn't manageable

reviewText: Absoultely amazing looking game. The various enviornments you see in the game are all very well designed. Sound effects are loud and impactful. Suit abilities add variety to the strategies of this fps. Being able to cloak and sprint quickly are vital if you wish to be succesful in Crysis. Enemies don't vary much but are intelligent and very precise. Vehicles handle fairly well and come in handy when traversing large areas. Story is pretty straight forward but voice actors do a fantastic job and the dialogue is enjoyable. Campaign was a bit short but decent enough length for an fps. If you have a good enough machine to max the settings on this game it is deffinetely a treat to look at, even to this day. 8.5/10

reviewText:
OMG!
Uneliveabley good, still stands up to some modern day shooters!
Dont go thinking this is a run head in, guns ' a 'blazin kind of game...no,no,no,no....you will be D.E.A.D my friend!
This is more of a thinking mans FPS, as about 3-5 shots will kill you!  You can make yourself invisable (but only for a short while) , Super Strong (throttle men with your bare hands!) Super fast (Run Forest, Run!) or super resilent to damage.
But only one skill at a time, which requires you to choose your tactics wisely, everyone will play the game differently and the levels are pretty sandboxy to go whichever direction you desire to complete the mission.

You would be dissapointed....just GET IT !!!!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I played this game just recently and must say, even though around 6 years have passed since its release, Crysis still have much to offer. Perhaps I haven't played modern FPS much but for me graphics are still very good, somtimes even impressive. Sound, music and voice acting are also great - they're building tension and atmosphere. Story is good and have couple of really memorable moments. However what's best about the game is freedom - whether you prefer stealth approach or going gun blazing - you can play however you want (apart from few 'boss fight' where you have to demolish stuff). It hard to tell exactly but I think it took me around 5-6 hours on normal to finish single player campaign.\n\nAs I mentioned I played it 6 years after release so I didn't even try to run multiplayer. It's EA after all - I assumed all servers are already down by now.

reviewText: [9/10] - Crysis is one of those rare games that grabs you by the crotch, and shakes you around a bit, but in a good way. It's hard to find games with devotion to detail, gameplay, and story but this fits the bill very nicely. It's a long length game, has a great story, and has even better gameplay. With different suit capabilities, you control how the game is played. From straight through gamers, to stealth junkies, and even speed demons, this game lets you choose how  the experience feels to you. You have to play it to understand, but it is hands-down a must have for FPS lovers.

reviewText: This game looks incredible. It's beautiful to look at. There are segments that make you gasp at how good it looks. Other than that, the game is pretty good. The weapons are standard, the armor is fun to use, and the stealth is good. The controls are kind of dumb, like the fact that the ADS is a toggle, not a hold, and the level design is somewhat complicated and unintuitive. The story is good, and it balances stealthy covert operations, all-out warfare, and alien invasion very well. The vehicles are, however, complete garbage on wheels. They do no damage, are nearly impossible to see out of, and can take about ten shots before destruction. Overall, a good game, but the graphics are where you will get your money's worth.
